reviewText: But how great is that? Brain power is required to get the most out of this. Lot's of coincidences, but that's ok. Because there is great acting here. And a terrifying, hope-this-never happens to me and mine reaction. Heartbreak on the screen. And monsters. That look like us. It is very good at what it wants to do. Finally a movie for the mature of all ages. No explosions. How refreshing.

This is a wrenching plot because we don't know WHO to suspect. We share the anguish of the parents whose daughters have gone missing and the woman whose nephew is suspected of taking them. At one point I thought I had seen so many MacGuffins I could open a shop, but then, Lo and Behold, each of those little devices became big ones, so pay attention!

With a script by Aaron Guzikowski ("Contraband") and directed by Canadian Denis Villeneuve ("Incendies"), we are wrung out by the frantic action and the heartfelt misery that unfolds before our unwilling eyes. The most outstanding feature is authenticity: The family interactions and the locations. I would have changed some of the dialogue and completely eliminated one "Gotcha" moment.

Here is the sterling cast:
  * Hugh Jackman ("Wolverine") is Keller Dover, a building contractor who lives with his wife and two children in a pleasant middle-class neighborhood. It is his frantic quest to find his daughter that is central to the plot. He says, "Pray for the best, prepare for the worst."
  * Maria Bello ("The Company Men") is Keller's wife, Grace. As one empty day follows another, she begins to lose hope.
  * Jake Gyllenhaal ("Source Code") is Detective Loki, a weary, relentless investigator who hasn't lost a case yet. The girls' parents are frustrated by his unhurried pace.
  * Viola Davis ("The Help") is Nancy Birch, mother of the second missing girl. She has to examine her own principles and humanity when confronted by the evidence.
  * Terrance Howard ("Red Tails") is her husband Franklin, Keller's unwilling collaborator.
  * Melissa Leo ("The Fighter") is Holly Jones, a resourceful widow who has raised her mentally impaired nephew.
  * Paul Dano ("Ruby Sparks") is her nephew Alex. He has the mental age of a ten year old.

Three things I should mention: 1) This takes place in a chilly, damp locale; take a sweater. 2) This runs 153 minutes; limit your liquids. 3) This is an R-rated thriller; expect explosive action and a LOT of profanity.

The DVD will have captions, which I sorely needed a few times. I've already asked Amazon to notify me when it is available.

It seems Denis Villeneuve is pretty self-impressed and has a tendency to make movies much too long and fills them with a lot of non-essential long shots. Ive recently seen four of his movies and really only liked one Sicario. I did Blade Runner 2049 the night before and it suffered from the same ills of this one in that it lacked a story that could support the length of the film. This one was boring enough in many spots that I had to do an Internet search on plot points I missed while actually watching the movie. There just isn't enough happening in this movie to warrant a runtime of 2 hours, 33 minutes and its stuck in a confining small town with few characters and no one is really doing much to keep the viewer entertained. There is a lot of footage that would have been much better left on the cutting room floor and more focus on some of the plot points.

Maybe I wasn't in the right mood this time, but the first time I saw Prisoners I liked it just a tad more. Hugh Jackman plays a Dad trying desperately to find his disappeared daughter, and Jake Gyllenhaal the seasoned detective trying to actually solve the crime without punching said Dad in the face. The good?  The story and script ask real moral question about who is the criminal, and who is the prisoner. The Bad? Jackman's character is a bit more over the top than I would have liked - his hysterical brow-beating of Gyllenhaal's detective is not quite authentic enough. So, when the worm turns (no spoilers here) I'm not sure he has really earned it, and Gyllenhaal's character is just a bit too unfazed by everything. Nonetheless, these are really more quibbles. Overall, Prisoners delivers the goods, and the real scene stealers in the film are Paul Dano's remarkable turn as the suspected kidnapper and even more so Melissa Leo's truly eeirie performance as "Ma."
This is a FANTASTIC movie!!!  My family has watched this 3-4 times.  If you like Suspense, Thrillers...and great acting, you will love this one.  Paul Dano is in this too and does a great job.

This film is absolutely incredible. Most newer movies I have seen are quite terrible, but this movie shatters any and all low expectations. This is a slow burning thriller centered around the emotional abduction of two children. Prisoners is a mysterious puzzle in which the pieces do not fit together until the very end. The cast of characters was well picked. I would like to mention that if you have ever seen The Lovely Bones, this movie is the oppisite end. It focuses on the misery of the parents and the hell on Earth they go through while trying to find their children. In content, it is in juxtaposition of The Lovely Bones. There is nothing fluffy or whimsical about Prisoners. It is very sad, very real, and jarring.

Standard fair for the murder mystery genre Hollywood's fame is built on. "L.A. Confidential"  is but one of scores (literally hundreds) of this type that qualify as a model for the cookie cutter process to work so effectively. Use the old adage - If you've  seen one  - you've seen them all and you'll be in good company. The acting was more than satisfactorily enjoyable - just the results where (or seemed to be)  to predictable. Low - to medium dose of language in the F*** word category mixed with a fair dose of blood and guts; and you've got the aforementioned plot carried out to a tee. For a $5 movie its okay - any thing more than that - then you would probably be just as well off looking for a good Marvel Comic's based flick. JMHO.

SPOILER ALERT
The film is way too long, a lot of unnecessary shots, no real emotion on Hugh Jackman's part and one of the most significant fatal flaws in my mind  absolutely no humour, not a pinch. It's a gritty film (and I get it), but please give me a break! An experienced writer would be able to lighten up the mood and that is a must from time to time.
Now, the inconsistencies, silly red herrings and just plain stupidity: Why would the child killer go to confess to a priest when his faith dwindled after his son died and they waged war against God? The priest confirmed that the killer was "bragging"  so what is exactly the point of going to the priest? Does not sound like a confession issue to me. Fail
Why didn't they get the priest to do a photofit and connect the dots that way? If you kill a man you sure remember at least something of him? Why didn't the maverick detective think about the old Auntie's husband going missing all those years ago and perhaps make some sort of connection? Nah, it's not good for the plot. Fail
The same maverick detective-solved-all-the-cases finds everything out by chance  by chance he sees the cable sticking out from behind a cupboard which (surprise, surprise!) is hiding a secret entrance to a secret basement and the priest never even thought of getting rid of the body. Then, by chance again, the maverick detective shoves all the stuff on the floor from his desk and voila!  A clue again! Fail

Why did Hugh Jackman's character need to beat the mentally disabled Alex  when the genius detective interviewed him, it seemed the phobia of human touch did the job? Plus, Keller never got anything out of Alex although Alex's capable  when the plot requires  to utter a completely coherent and revealing sentence. Also, everybody would of course believe the disabled guy but not the father trying to find his missing child. Where was surveillance? Oh, my next point  the whole police force consists of the genius detective, his superior with an office, a couple of administrative guys and a forensic team of 2  get outta here! The genius detective does not only seem to have no training but lacking in common sense as well  why would you not close the first snake box and let the snakes get out whilst you're opening other boxes? This is just idiotic. Fail

Everybody seem to be talking in riddles  the girl that escaped utters "you were there", everybody seem to hear it, see Keller run out like mad, but for the plot purposes, nobody reacts. Instead of questioning the girl (who, we've just witnessed, can actually speak!), they just stand around in a friendly circle. Fail
Keller goes to the auntie's house knowing full well that she's a serial killer and (one in such extreme situation would gather)  very dangerous. He TURNS HIS BACK to her and mutters a threat. For what I know, she could have knocked him out with a frying pan at that point. Fail
The evil Auntie, weirdly, seems to be repeating every command twice  open the drawer x 2, get in the car x 2, everything's repeated twice  are the writers short of words? What's going on? Fail
Oh, and a note to the director  try cutting the scenes down or eliminate the ones with people just walking down the hospital corridors  may add urgency to the pace and people would not doze off whilst watching a 2.5 hour film the story of which does not warrant this length.

Excellent thriller with lots of things to think about later.  The title, we think, applies to all the situations and characters, who are trapped in situations they cannot escape.  Calendar holidays rule our lives.  Bad bosses rule our jobs.  Various marriages.  Children.  Mental states.  The clues mainly relate to the facts revealed in the plot, like in any standard mystery, but they are satisfyingly easy to miss.  Thank God for cult religions and other types, ruling our thoughts and actions, but often sinned against.  Wow, what a movie!  Must see again and show to family and friends.  Not for kids.  Ultra violent, which fits the story well.  Almost up to the Mulholland Drive top complexity movie.  Not a fantasy like MD but otherwise perfect.

Prisoners is an incredibly gripping, riveting story well written, cast, performed, directed, edited. An amazing team of talent that puts the viewer closely inside a believable story of abduction, desperation, unyielding determination, simultaneously through the ways of the law, vigilante justice, and the abductors. Prisoners draws you in, spins you around, then puts you in a moment of suspended disbelief, leaving you simply with...wow. On the downside, fundamental  to the story, Davis and Howard's roles are somewhat diminished by Gyllenhall and Jackman, with a shared emphasis on finding Anna, Jackmans daughter.

You could cut a diamond with the stare that he directed at Paul Dano in the police department at the start of the movie. He's almost like Medusa in the sense that you'd need a mirror to look him in the eyes when he stares at you in order to avoid serious bodily harm.

Both Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman give amazing, believable performances. It earned this 5-star review.

This movie has been sitting on my shelf for nearly a year. I received it as a gift for Christmas given my love of of the film's leading men, unfortunately it seemed like every time I sat down to watch it something would come up. Today I was finally successful. It was a great movie, though one that I'm in no hurry to watch again. Run time clocks in at just a little over two and a half hours. I personally like longer films, provided the material is there. A longer run time can give a director time to expand the story, flesh out the characters and the world. But on the flip side, if the material is lacking, it creates a sluggish pace for the viewer.

Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) and his family are attending Thanksgiving dinner with Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard) and his family. Both families have two children, a teenager and young daughter. Despite the friendship between the families, there are some clear class and character differences. Over the course of the day the younger daughters, Anna and Joy, go missing. The search to find the girls and how far a parent will go become the driving plot of the film. Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) is assigned to the case. While he assures Keller that he is doing everything that he can and that he will find the girls, this seems to go in one ear and out the other. Loki has no children of his own, he's younger than Keller, and from a parent's standpoint it seems like he could be trying just a bit harder to solve the case. It's easy to see and feel Keller's frustration with the situation, which is why it's of no surprise that he takes matters into his own hands. Using the decrepit apartment building, his deceased father left him, Keller takes Alex (Paul Dano), the only suspect as far as he's concerned, and holds him hostage. In this situation he tortures Alex for information about his daughter as well as the Birch daughter. Unfortunately, Alex has the mental capacity of a ten year old which means it gets ugly. As the movie progresses and the story lines begin to intersect, it becomes a question of just how far down the rabbit hole the whole thing will go. The material is reminiscent of something one might see on Criminal Minds, however there's no real profiling of the kidnapper. And some viewers may find the motive to a be a bit disappointing.

The plot is captivating and convincing. The viewer wants to know how it all ends. Are the girls found? Are they alive? Did Alex take them? And how far will Keller go to find his daughter? I assure you the title of the film is no coincidence. While on the surface it would appear that the title refers to the missing girls, each of the characters becomes a prisoner in their own way. The story and setting remind us that these things happen every day. They could happen in our very town, no matter how sleepy and picturesque it might be. Perhaps it's that sense of realism about the film that makes it so good.

I do have a few complaints about the film, though they are not enough to really detract from my overall impression. The male characters are more fleshed out than the female characters. Viola Davis (Nancy Birch), Maria Bello (Grace Dover), and Melissa Leo (Holly Jones) all feel like secondary characters. There's no real room for character growth for any of them. We get one scene each to sum up the character's emotions and state of mind. Despite the fact that these characters are all affected by the disappearance of Anna and Joy, they receive relatively no airtime. The film also has a bit of an ambiguous ending, where the viewer must decide for themselves how it truly ends. That's not to say the central plot isn't resolved by the time the credits roll, it is. But don't expect everything to be wrapped up in a neat little bow. That's not real life and the film is a startling reminder of that.

All in all, I'd give the film 4 out of 5 stars. If you're a fan of the crime/thriller/mystery type genre, it's a great film. Good script, solid performances by the characters throughout. Definitely worth checking out.

I don't have much to add to the other negative reviews of this steaming pant-load, except to ask what significance the name "Loki" had for the Jake Gyllenhall character.  He's called "Detective Loki," but we never learn if it's his first or last name, or if he has only one name, like "Prince."  Also, Loki is the Norse god of evil - how does that make sense?  It would have made more sense if they'd called him "Baldur" the god of light, or even "Hodur" the blind god since he couldn't find his way or something.

Otherwise, at least an hour of this film should have ended up on the cutting room floor, and the remainder would have had more plot holes than a Sierpinski gasket.  I can only recommend this to diehard fans of Jake Gyllenhall, or anyone who enjoys seeing Huge Ackman screaming in rage, and especially anyone who despises Paul Dano and wants to see him suffer.

On the surface, this looks like a bog standard police procedural thriller; children go missing, one obvious suspect, insufficient evidence, angry father, blah, blah, blah. In a lot of respects it is just what it seems but it still delivers tension, action and twists while refusing to conform to the much overused formula.

The atmosphere is splendidly bleak thanks to the grim Pennsylvanian November weather while the washed-out, nearly monochrome colour palette lends yet further grimness (its no wonder it earned an Oscar nomination for best cinematography). Couple this with cracking performances from Jackman & Gyllenhaal , magnificently managed tension from start to finish by a little known director, refreshingly anti -Catholic overtones and plenty of did-he-didnt-he plot twists you have the recipe for a sure-fire winner. It almost manages it too, but for the seemingly rushed ending and myriad loose-ends flapping about. The eventual unveiling of the culprit should have come as a surprise but, unfortunately, weve watched far too many dramas in this genre so we had sort-of worked out the connections long before the somewhat slow witted Gyllenhaal.

The ending could, of course, be deliberately Cohenesquely enigmatic, preferring to leave the viewer to fill in the gaps rather than providing a neat CSI-style i-dotting & t-crossing instantly forgettable ending but a bit of tidying-up would have been nice. Also, there are a good number of quiet and/or mumbling dialogue moments which require either a rewind or having the volume uncomfortable high.

I think I can mostly forgive the movies relatively minor failings though; it is an unusually dark, suspenseful, claustrophobic thriller, crammed with atmosphere and superb performances.

The writing and directing were very excellent. The running time is a bit long, running 153 minutes, or 2 hours and 33 minutes long. Part whodunnit, part psychological drama, "Prisoners" is an unrelenting look at at a man's stress-induced moral psychosis brought about by the kidnapping of his young daughter.  Hugh Jackman (as the father) and Jake Gyllenhahl as the dogged, flawed police investigator turn in career defining performances in what is a stark and mostly fast paced thriller with plenty of plot twists, turns, and a few surprises along the way.  With a dark and damp environment of grey skies, monsoon rains, and slick, snow-covered roads, Prisoners delivers a riveting and thoroughly believable portrait of mental illness (both temporary and transient) and the unique law enforcement individuals charged with hunting down criminals.

Rated a "Hard R" in my opinion for scenes of (implied and real) brutality and torture, with coarse language throughout.  Could have been edited down 10 minutes or so but this is a minor complaint.  Brilliant film.

Prisoners Review
 A truly good film must have two distinct qualities; an intriguing story and well-acted, interesting characters. The movie Prisoners came into theaters on September 20, 2013. The alluring story puts the audience on the edge of their seats while the superb acting married with a grim tone places them in an agonizing situation where the lines of good and evil are blurred. Prisoners exhibited brilliant performances from Hugh Jackman as a father willing to do whatever it takes to save his daughter, and Jake Gyllenhaal as the determined detective assigned to the complex case.
 Prisoners is a suspenseful drama that focuses on two families whose daughters are abducted in broad daylight on Thanksgiving day. Detective Loki, the police officer in charge of the case, quickly takes Alex Jones, who had been seen in the neighborhood that day, into custody. However, the man is soon released because of a lack of substantial evidence and the fact that he has the IQ of a ten year old. Immediately the audience is conflicted by this because Alex does seem to be innocent of the crime itself but also seems to know something. Keller Dover, the father of one of the stolen children, then takes matters into his own hands by abducting Alex and torturing him for information on the whereabouts of the girls. Here are where the lines first begin to blur, while you sympathize with Keller because of the disappearance of his daughter, you know that what he is doing is wrong. The audience sees a harsh contrast from the Keller we were introduced to at the beginning of the film and his descent into darkness. Meanwhile, Loki suspects a new man of abducting the children when he exhibits suspicious behavior at a candlelight vigil that is held for the girls. When the detective tracks the man down he finds boxes of bloody clothes, snakes, and mazes written along all of the walls in the house. The same type of maze had been found on the pendant of a murder victim located in the basement of a priest. During the mans interrogation Loki assaults him as his frustration explodes, further muddying the line between right and wrong. As detective Loki gets closer to putting all the clues together, Keller starts doubting that Alex really did take the girls. At this point the plot boils to a head to create a tension-filled and ambiguous ending that leaves the audience wanting more. While the overall plots of kidnapping and revenge aren't wholly original as Hughes points out, it is the way that the story is paired with a theme of conflict that makes the plot so intriguing.
The theme of conflict, which is intricately placed throughout the plot, would not have had the same effect that it does in Prisoners without the help of the brutal performances by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal.  It was his portrayal of this stubborn father that brought home the emotion and struggle of the character in these tough scenes that Schembri mentioned. This is especially evident in the torture scenes with Alex where Jackman manages to gain some sympathy from the audience, even while he is committing this heinous act. However, even Jackman did not overshadow Gyllenhaals biting performance as detective Loki. Throughout the film Loki has a distinct eye twitch which Gyllenhaal added. This twitch gave the character a sense of tense frustration which swells throughout the story. As Lokis frustration rises so does the tension the audience experiences, this is a credit to Gyllenhaals performance. Though both characters act in ways we might not, these actors were able to bring an understanding to their roles that made the audience battle with themselves and their feelings throughout the film.
Ultimately, Prisoners is a slow-building thriller that deals with a conflict between right and wrong through its gripping story fueled by enthralling performances. This film puts you in a place you would rather not be in while still managing to make you feel for the corrupt characters you are with throughout the movie. Prisoners, while everyone may not enjoy it, is sure to make its mark on cinema.

Prisoners is a riveting film. I've seen it twice now, picking up different things upon the second viewing. In addition to the direction, performances, music - all superb - the understated religious themes are profound; what a well-written original screenplay by Aaron Guzikowski. Detective Loki (Gyllenhaal) is something of a dark angel, with his mysterious tattoos, his twitching eyes (which pay off later during the film's climax), while Keller Dover (Jackman) is the man of original sin, his evil elicited by the kidnapping of his daughter. "I'm here to do my penance," Dover says in one scene near the end. And penance he does. While "Prisoners" is a noir-ish crime thriller and detective mystery, it shimmers with mysticism, a film at once rooted in humanity and elevated by something transcendent.

I am in my early 60s.
This film was Brutal. I knew from the opening scene (hunting) that there would be a classic "hunter becomes the hunted" theme.
In this case, it was so complex with many twists & turns. You'd think (after "Wolverine" & "Les Miserables") that Jackman's character would be the hero but he turned into a crazed man. Yes, desperation to find one's missing daughter would lead a person to do things out of the ordinary but I had to fast fwd through the repeated scenes of Keller Dover torturing mentally slow Alex Jones (played by Paul Dano, who did a great job in "There Will Be Blood" & "The Ballad of Jack & Rose"). That was absolutely too much violence for me. It helped that Franklyn Birch (Terrence Howard) felt bad about the brutalization & kept telling Keller to stop. But those scenes were far to horrific. And somehow, you know Alex didn't kidnap the little girls.
Melissa Leo ("Frozen River" & "Homicide: Life on the Streets") is one of my all-time favorite actresses & she did a strong turn here. But her cold, cruel, souless character turned my stomach.
Jake Gyllenhaal is brilliant as Det. Loki, who never gives up despite his endless frustration & all the obstacles in the investigation. He portrays a real person, not a 2 dimensional detective. I worked for the Boulder Police Dept/Detective Unit as a Gal Friday during one of the most horrific child murders of all time. I went on stake-outs, guarded the little boy's mother & stood as they dug the boy up. So I know how real detectives truly get involved emotionally, especially in child kidnapping/murder cases. Gyllenhaal was the hero of this story.
I love Maria Bello ("The Dark") & was angry when her TV show was cancelled. They didn't even give it a chance. She does a great job of showing the grief, the need to huddle in a dark room after her daughter goes missing.
The very end is unresolved. That left me frustrated. I am assuming that Loki finds the missing person (not going to spoil that one) but it was not shown. I much prefer resolved issues, even though I know from my own experience working in a Detective Unit, that some crimes are never solved. But in a movie, I want resolution!

Alas, a few more clues were given and the thought that caused the initial guess was out the window.  Acting, especially by Jackman and Gyllenhaal was great.  Gyllenhaal's detective character was played as being obsessed, not because of his perfect rate of clearance, but because it bothered him NOT to have answers.

I would suggest watching this movie in two parts.  Watch the first 1:45 and then walk away for a day.  The 15 minutes between 1:30 and 1:45 made the difference in whether you might return to the movie or not.  It was worth those 15 minutes!

I watched Prisoners for the first time this past weekend and was immediately wrapped up in the story. While the film is dark, brutal, and unpleasant, it is also entirely engaging.

As a distraught father whose daughter has been kidnapped, and finding little resolution via legal means, Hugh Jackman gives what may well be the performance of his career. He's an actor that is so closely entwined with the X-Men character, Wolverine, that I often forget just how solid of an actor he really his. Here, his talent is on full display as a man on the edge, pushed to the emotional brink. Gyllenhaal is solid, too, as the lead investigator, capturing the weary reality of his profession.

There's a lot of questionable morality at play here, and it's a bit too easy to root for Jackman's character, even he has he goes too far and does too many questionable things. Great, great movie, though. It kept me on the edge of my seat, and there's some really masterful layers and twists to the story. Every little scene plays fully into the overarching story, and the plot itself is almost as labyrinthine as the maze-like puzzles one character is obsessed with. Prisoners is a slow-boil of a film, but nothing gets wasted and there is no fat to trim, story-wise. Tonally, it reminds me a bit of David Fincher's ZODIAC, which is also highly recommended (and another deliberately paced crime flick with Gyllenhaal front and center). I'll be adding this film to my buy list for sure!

This is a dark, dark, dark movie, every bit as tense and disturbing as I been led to believe it would be. Like most good mysteries, there are a few red herrings along the way but the reveal of the kidnapper's identity and connection to the other characters makes sense contextually -- you can re-watch the movie and see where the hints were dropped, and they do all line up.  One of my biggest complaints with mysteries, whether written or filmed, is when the writers/directors are so interested in being surprising/shocking with their twist endings that they don't play fair with the audience. (IMHO, the only time that's okay is in a canonical Sherlock Holmes story, and even then it's frustrating.)

Performance-wise, I don't think there's a missed opportunity or poor performance in the lot.

Hugh Jackman takes Keller Dover from God-fearing, stand-up family man to some very very dark places ... without spoiling anything other than what the movie's trailers did, he morphs from distraught father to angry detective to a man who sees no other option but to continue on the path he's on, even if that path ends his life and damns his soul. The movie opens with Jackman reciting The Lord's Prayer, so we know he's a religious man; he recites it while watching his teenage son shoot and kill his first deer, so we know he's also a practical man who wants his family to have every chance to survive anything that might happen (the basement is stocked to survive a massive power failure, for example).  Near the movie's end, he recites it again, and the difference in intonation and pacing shows us just how far Keller has descended.

Jaky Gyllenhal's character is saddled with the unfortunate name of Detective David Loki. I say "unfortunate" only because, hearing the character's name in the trailers, I assumed he'd be far more of a trickster character than he turns out to be. He does his best to investigate the girls' disappearance, and he does put some connections together than none of the other policemen (what few we see), but he doesn't seem to be very tricksterish.  Overall, I liked Gyllenhal's performance as much as Jackman's, except for the facial tic he displays.

I will agree with others who have said that Terrence Howard and Voila Davis are a bit under-used, but the same can be said of Maria Bello. Once the situation is introduced and Keller starts down his dark path, the other three parents become increasingly less important to moving the plot forward. Each one does have at least one powerhouse scene that plays to their strengths.  In fact, so does Dylan Minnette, the only one of the four Dover and Birch kids to get significant screen time. Over the past few years, directors have really started to notice Minnette's intensity and he's getting larger and stronger roles. His scenes in Prisoners with Jackman run from a son who idolizes his father to one who cannot contain the betrayal and anguish he feels at what he perceives to be his father's failing.  He's a teen to watch.

The other stand-out performance is from Paul Dano, who is virtually unrecognizable as Alex Jones. It's not just the make-up (stringy hair, slightly overweight padding, thick glasses), it's the performance. He's so invested in the character there isn't a glimmer of Dano present.  Melissa Leo is also wonderful as Alex's aunt Holly.

Hugh Jackman plays Keller Dover, whose daughter Anna (Erin Gerasimovich) goes missing on a rainy Thanksgiving Day, together with his best friend Franklins (Terrence Howard) daughter Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons). Although a suspect is soon apprehended, the police have to release him, having no conclusive evidence.

While the police detective David Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) continues to investigate, Keller, unsatisfied with the way the police handle with the case, attempts to find the missing daughters on his own. This means the father is determined to do whatever it takes to save his daughter's life  even breaking laws.

Those who have seen the Canadian directors previous work Incendies (nominated for Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film in 2011) know that his Hollywood debut is nothing ordinary. Not many thrillers run 153 minutes these days, do they?

As a thriller Prisoner really requires suspending disbelief, as some parts are too good to be true, but thanks to the powerhouse acting from the entire cast and the brooding photography of Roger Deakins, the film is an emotionally charged, morally complicated drama.

Prisoners is a prime example of why I will never understand Hollywood. You've got a truly great story, an all-star cast, and a world renowned Director, making his American debut. Prisoners was considered to be an Oscar caliber film before it was even released, yet for some reason they had to make it nearly three hours long. If there was enough story for a three hour film, then I'd be all for it, but Prisoners has a good 45 minutes worth of repetitiveness, that does nothing to help the movie, in fact, it takes something away from the film. The story begins on Thanksgiving, when two little girls go outside to play and disappear. Feeling that the police aren't doing enough to find the kids, one father (Hugh Jackman) decides to take matters into his own hands. Hugh Jackman stars in a role I wouldn't have imagined him playing in a million years. Based on his other roles and what I know about the man, this doesn't even seem like the kind of role he'd be interested in, but he gives one of the strongest performances I've seen all year, I really didn't know he had that in him. Jackman is paired by Jake Gyllenhaal, another guy who I couldn't see playing a tough as nails police detective, but he too surprised, giving a very strong performance. The cast isn't the problem and the story isn't the problem, what bothered me about this film was how much of it was unnecessary. Did we really need dozens of scenes with Jackman and Dano or all the talk and sadness amongst the families? This was a great all-around movie, but it was so long, that by the end, I'd stopped caring about what was happening and just wanted it to be over. Don't get me wrong, I highly recommend this film for a unique twist on classic story, great performances from an unlikely cast, and the work of a Director who his known around the world for his signature style, but just a word of caution. Prisoners is a very long film, that at many points seems to go around in circles. When they eventually do get to the point, it's outstanding, but it takes a while to get there.

This movie has a familiar plot of two little girls who have gone missing and the subsequent search for them and the suspects.  I am a fan of crime dramas and with this type of plot I'm always hoping for something different and surprising.  Unfortunately, although the movie throws in a couple of twists in an attempt to mislead the viewer, I thought the ultimate outcome was predictable and similar to movies/TV shows I've seen in the past.

The movie has a big name cast and I felt that Jake Gyllenhaal (as Detective Loki) was very edgy and the most  interesting.  Paul Dano (the prime suspect) and Melissa Leo (the suspect's aunt) were very good.  Hugh Jackman (as Keller Dover, one of the missing girl's father) had the lead role in the movie and I was not overly impressed by his acting.  He was basically a vigilante type father and I didn't like his character and didn't sympathize with his plight.

The length of the movie (at 2 hours 33 minutes) was overly long.  It seemed to me that High Jackman was given a lot of screen time to vent his anger at the detective and prime suspect.  *Possible Spoiler Alert Follows*.  The filmmakers must have thought that Jackman's  kidnapping and torture of the prime suspect was a highlight of the film and warranted more screen time.  I thought it was pretty repulsive and backfired as it made me dislike his character more (almost but not quite as much as the child abductor).

This movie started out with some interesting twists but quickly became a long drawn out mess.  It seemed to drag on and on for no apparent reason.  This is another predictable poorly made movie, a dollar rental at best.

I bought this for my son for Christmas, and he loves this movie.  Glad I got this for him and I will order more for him if he wants me too for next Christmas.

It could be at least 4 different people depending how you want to work with the definition of "prisoner!"  The angry father feels imprisoned as does his family since they can't find their missing daughter, the missing daughter could be interpreted as a prisoner, the cop would fit the bill as well since he's on the case but getting nowhere most of the time... even the bad guys!  Yes, "Prisoners" is an interesting title for the movie.

Anyway without a DOUBT the number one reason Prisoners is such a great film is due to the extraordinary acting of Hugh Jackman.  When I say he's awesome in his role as the parent who desperately wants to find his missing daughter, I wasn't expecting him to basically turn into a possessed monster!  He will do absolutely *anything* to find her and can be deliberate, intense, angry, vengeful... you name it!  I knew Hugh Jackson was a fantastic actor- I think most of us knew that already going into Prisoners, but I guess I either had a lapse of judgment and forgot or just didn't realize how powerful he can be in the roles he plays, especially given the very frightening and realistic material he has to work with here.

Hugh Jackson is so believable in his role that he should be winning best actor of the year for a role this good.  Maybe I just got caught up in the mystery and the suspense of the film so much that I'm simply blinded with bias so I apologize if it sounds like I'm exaggerating a bit, but he deserves *some* kind of accolade for his role.  Let's get to the movie instead of all this Hugh Jackman gushing shall we? :)

I don't want to spoil what happens for a good chunk of the film but I might have to since not mentioning it is almost unavoidable.  This is a minor spoiler however, this next part.  Hugh finds and captures a mentally disturbed man who has the mindset of a 10-year old.  Hugh believes this man is responsible for the kidnapping of not only his daughter, but his friends daughter as well.  Hugh even hears the man singing a song that his daughter was singing the day she disappeared, sending distinct warning signs that he's the guilty one.  Hugh basically kidnaps and tortures the man, and keeps the body hidden in an old rundown and abandoned apartment building.  When Hugh's done torturing for the day, he returns the next day and keeps going without remorse.  Don't try to reason with Hugh either- he already thought the situation out clearly and won't let a simple disagreement that what he's doing is wrong stop him from processing with the torturing.  Basically Hugh's absolutely crazy in the head and proves he's willing to do anything to find his daughter.  He takes it to a whole new level!

However the other major chunk of storytelling is about the cop (played by Jake Gyllenhaal) who ALMOST ruins the movie in my opinion due to his poor acting, nonchalant attitude, total disinterest in doing his job and finding the two daughters, feeling inconvenienced whenever Hugh Jackman expresses rage and accuses him of not trying hard enough (which is correct, the cop's NOT trying hard enough to find the two daughters- at least for a while).  Now some of this can be attributed to the storytelling- the writers wanted a laidback and lazy cop to search for clues in this small town.  However some of it is completely unintentional.  Jake just doesn't possess the right kind of emotions depending on the situation at hand.  He often comes across more like a rookie unaware how to react in certain situations.  Not sure if intentional or not.  I think someone else should have played the cop role instead.

This movie even shows the mother/wife of Hugh Jackman, and how distraught and unable she is to cope with the disappearance of her daughter in believable fashion so she stays in bed depressed all the time.  While a good chunk of this movie is slow-moving, mystery-related drama, there's clearly *another* chunk of the writing that is suspenseful concerning how Hugh Jackman responds to the man he captures.  This is a mighty fine movie regardless of Jake Gyllenhaal almost dragging it down.  The only problem is the end of the film.  It doesn't provide the kind of closure that it clearly COULD have.  The movie needs at least one more minute to wrap everything up.  I mean they were *so* close!  Just one more minute would have done it!  Anyway the final 20 minutes are downright AWESOME despite the ending.  Several twists and turns.  Great great movie.
Awesomwe movie! This could relate to the real life things that people would do for their family. Excellent storyline, I can not say much more without giving away the movie.
Lived up to the expectations. One of the best movies I have watched all year long. Looking to purchase it as well.

I thought a lot of this movie was wasted on the aspect of misleading the audience so that we believed it was always the other guy, or that guy, the movie had a lot of making people point fingers at each other.

On another lighter note, the movie was not as gruesome as I thought it would be. The gruesome scenes are short and too the point, however they are pretty terrible while you're watching. So don't feel bad if you have to hide your eyes for a few minutes, believe me the dialogue will help you know what is going on, even if you're not looking.

While I did enjoy this move, I found it to be a little over-analytical for my taste. Would I recommend it to other people? Yes, I would especially those with children. I think its important to know how far you would go for your child. Though for most the answer is easy, all the way. For Hugh Jackman, the answer is the same.
It is hard to say I loved this movie...the plot was morbid, and exposed the darker elements of  otherwise decent human beings, as they are pushed by their desires to protect their world.

This movie really dragged on but at the same time I never felt like turning it off. There was just enough suspense left hanging after every scene that made my curiosity spike. It was a slow start, slow getting to the midpoint, slow to reach the climax and an even slower resolution. It leaves you, sort of, holding your breath and never really provides the sigh of relief. If you have the time and patience for a seemingly never-ending movie you may find yourself really enjoying the story though.  There is a certain level of terror that I think people with children can find relatable.

The best type of father, the best type of cop, the worst evil plaguing humanity--this movie smashes the three together into a heart-wrenching, tense, intelligent, and thrilling story.  Everything is done well.  The acting is perfect.  The character actions are realistic, believable, and enthralling.  The story just keeps piling on tension and mystery, making you wonder how facets fit together until the very end.

Very disturbing.  Very creative.  With an excellent ending and a few nice twists.

Sometimes, extreme measures are the right measures.  Especially when dealing with these types of criminals.  You will get a satisfying dose of violence--unfortunately tempered by the realities of our justice system and the ingenuity of evil human beings.

This movie is a winner.  SEE IT NOW.  You will NOT regret it.
This movie my boyfriend really likes. He enjoys these kind of movies. We will be watching for more of the same kind.

My Sister told me I HAVE TO SEE THIS MOVIE.I love all the actors,and what a great plot,but not a good movie. I paid attention for 2and a half hours thinking something great is going to happen,but It didn't.
Great, intense movie!  Wish I would watch it again but you only get to rent it for twenty four hours.

Largely devoid of any dramatic tension, a police search for two missing girls last seen near a camper parked in the neighborhood drags on for 2-1/2 uninvolving hours, with a routine police search led by Jake Gyllenhaal as a detective, looking somewhat bizarre in slicked-back hair and knit cap.  Hugh Jackman portrays one of the girls' fathers, who snaps and kidnaps a released suspect and tortures him.  The script is mediocre and bland, the plot full of holes and never really engaging, and the actors are largely going through the motions.  My condolences to the good actors who wasted their time on this, including Viola Davis and Terrence Howard.
Worst police force ever. Jake...maybe have another cop ride with you?  Hugh...don't turn your back on people you suspect...on and on. Gruesome. Skip this one.

Though there were some really disturbing violent scenes, the movie was very thrilling with many twists and turns,  It was a very realistic and believable story depicting the nature of humans involved in a prisoner situation.  I thought about the themes for days later!
Would recommend..not boring..... (sorry I have to add more words how stupid on regulating how long are reviews are) lame
I enjoyed this movie very much. Great performances by both Jackman and Gillilenhal (or however you spell his name). Recommend.
I have a 4 year old so I was a little freaked out at first but then the movie took a twist. I would definitely recommend.
Loved it!! The ending will shock you! I didn't expect it to end the way it did. Would watch it again, and recommend it to friends and family!
The sound on this movie was messed up. We couldn't watch it. It might be good but I couldn't tell.

I chose this movie because a friend saw it and recommended it to me.
I liked the film because I enjoy suspense and I love Hugh Jackman.
I would also recommend his movie.

A very well wrought suspense/thriller, which, although no masterpiece, is well above average in its genre. It is a dark, moody and generally downbeat movie with just enough momentum to keep one's interest from flagging. The wintery atmosphere is very well captured, and the constant intrigue as to who may be the abductor of the missing daughter keeps the whole thing well together.
This is not the kind of film which I would want to see again, since its bleakness simply doesn't invite a revisit. Still, on its own terms it is well worth a watch, and in no way disappoints.

I'd recommend this movie to anyone who doesn't mind intense plots or violence. It's not a slasher film by any means, and I wouldn't classify it as a horror either. It's probably closer to a thriller, or a dark drama. It's an interesting movie that is sure to keep any viewer entertained. I'd probably not show it to the kids, but that's your call.
The movie grabs you from start to finish. The tone is very uneasy maintained with twist after twist. Great acting and a quality script. Best movie I saw this year.
i liked the movie plot and its dark nature.  I was however left with some questions that will have me wondering.  Anyway it was a good rental

I'm a huge movie buff and I haven't been on the edge of my seat in a long while.  You will be taken on a ride of emotions, unsure of where to go.  Just when you think you have it figure out, the zinger at the end is pure genius! See it!
Exciting, well made, unpredictable, and with good actors. Maybe a bit long, over two hours, but well worth he session.

Really good movie, intense! Great empathy for the characters. I can imagine being a vigilante under those circumstances. You don't want to believe but there are so many missing children taken by really sick people.

This is one of the best thrillers in a while. It reminds me of the movie Seven that came out 20 years ago. Fans of the movie Zodiac and Winter's Bone may also find this movie masterful. There is a moody atmosphere to the entire movie that is very well stylized. The cast also had great chemistry and acting. The directing is really well done, the story keeps you guessing the entire time. I felt like this movie lived up to the hype of the preview. People who hate moody depressing films may hate this movie.
A little confusing at times but overall a good movie. I did not like the way it ended at all
Really good movie. Some of the scenes are hard to watch, but the scenes really high-light what happens to some people under extreme stress.

That was a good movie.  Had trouble deciding between 3 or four stars but went ahead with the four stars.  It had a great story and was not as predictable as it seemed.  Great cast and all in all a good movie.

This is a great story. It's a little dark due to the subject matter. But there is no dwelling on violence or horror as a gimmick to keep your attention. You can't understand the play on words of the title until you have seen the movie. It's a who done it, mystery, vigilante horror (not like SAW or something) movie all in one.

First of all i wouldnt even give this movie a 1 star, but since it wouldnt let me leave a review without checking one....And i have never wrote a review about anything, but im doing it for this movie because i feel sick right now.
 I don't know why anybody would want to watch this movie. Quite simply put, its a parents worst nightmare, and im still trying to figure out how who sits around and creates such awful things, and puts it out there as a form of art. That movie should be illegal; its content is that horrendous!
Dont watch it, don't buy it. Dont give your time to watch a story about such god awful things. If you're a parent, DON'T WATCH IT!

Wow, a bit twisted, but I liked this strange movie.  Tense, unpredictable and kept me engaged.  Worthy of adult movie night.

Wow, wow, wow!!! I couldn't get off the edge of my couch! It encompasses some highly disturbing issues, but very suspenseful and fantastic acting.

well, the ending although it alludes to a definite conclusion - had me for a sec, but this was a really good movie
I was so happy to get this movie as it is really good was better than I thought; See it

I really looked forward to seeing this film having heard good things about it and loved the actors involved.  It started interestingly enough with a father and son hunt on Thanksgiving morning then things turn dark.  The cast is strong, but I believed underused.  There was no attempt to develop chemistry between the characters and I didn't once believe that Viola Davis and Terrance Howard were a couple.  Jake G. and Hugh J. benefit from their screen time and give strong performances.  Ultimately, it's Melissa Leo's quiet, steady performance I found the strongest.  Leo is a great actress.

As a thriller, I recommend this movie.  I think folks may find it a bit slow as we have become accustomed to cookie cutter thrillers where the who, what, where and how is telegraphed or answered quickly.  Prisoners takes an all too familiar story and through it's characters gives us something different.  I just wished the characters had more depth and some more to do.
Keeps you at the edge of your seat - so gave it five stars - pretty decent considering what else is out there!

Excellent! A twist on the plot that was done so well the ending was perfection. Jackman and Gyllenhaal noticeably became character actors for their roles in the movie - superb performances by both men. Supporting characters deserve a nod as well. Easily 5 stars.

As a parent/grandparent I found the actions of the main character very realistic if not a little "old school". I am NOT politically correct for the sake of "getting along". I liked the characters, story, but the ending had me saying...."Well?"
Excellent Movie. I don't know anyone who wouldn't feel the same as they did if you where in their situation. It all comes together in the end. With a twist!

Every so often I see a movie that I can't get out of my head; a movie so fascinating, compelling and intricate and I can think of nothing else for days afterward. Prisoners is one such film. The movie focuses on two families whose daughters disappear on Thanksgiving day, and the subsequent search for them. Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), the father of one of the little girls, takes matters into his own hands when the police fail to make any progress in the search. He becomes more and more rash and irrational, his methods more and more extreme. This is not Taken with Liam Neeson. This is a man who prepares for every situation and disaster, and loses it when he's faced with a crisis he never thought to prepare for. Hugh Jackman's Keller is frantic, angry and above all, desperate. His is a loud, red hot, full blooded performance that fully conveys the sense of anguish, rage, and fear that someone in his position would endure. The film asks the audience to consider how far is too far when it comes to your children's well-being. What would you do? Jake Gyllenhaal, in an interesting turn, plays the detective assigned to the case. Where Jackman's performance is showy (in a good way), Gyllenhaal turns in a layered, subtly nuanced performance. He is the long-suffering force that everyone in the film turns to for help, as well as to lay blame. But my favorite part of the movie is the cinematography. Its gorgeous. Every frame of the film is considered and precise. It is one of the most well filmed movies I've ever seen. It looks incredible on bluray, and I sometimes put the film in just to see some of the beautiful photography in it.

With intricate and engaging writing, intentional editing, arresting cinematography and powerful performances, I can't for the life of me figure out how this film flew under the radar this Oscar season. But either way, this is a thrilling and powerful piece of cinema. It has its issues, mostly concerning some possible plotholes and a line or two of only passable dialogue, but the film is so engrossing that they are easy to overlook, and even easier to forgive. At the end of the day, this is a layered and intense near- masterpiece. Oscar worthy (not sure how much of a complement that is anymore) direction, performances and cinematography in one of the very best films of 2013.
Overall it was an okay movie, but it goes slow and the end I didn't care about because the little girl and daddy reunion wasn't shown!

This is a very dark tale with some twists, turns and some confusing, ambiguous messages. I'm a sucker for a gripping mystery/drama so I was drawn in. I of course checked the locks on my doors, checked in on my children and will now be hovering over them 24/7 like a helicopter...

This movie gave me the creeps. The lengths to which Hugh Jackman's character was willing to go to find his daughter and the back-story that unfurls is riveting (though somewhat predictable). It's definitely a crime thriller, but the story is different enough from others I have seen that it held my interest.
This movie had many twists and turns that keeps you on your toes.  My husband and I both loved it!

Best movie I have seen in a long, long time. However, I believe there will be a sequel. They left so many unanswered questions and I was in shock when they ended it not knowing if the police detective found the father!! What did little Joy mean when she looked at Hugh Jackman and accused him of "putting tape on their mouth"? It must have been someone that looks like him, right?

You just cannot end a movie like that and not expect a sequel...
Well acted movie but a few major plot holes that were distracting. Check out movie, enjoy it but watch carefully for the story logic holes.
This is a great movie with a lot of twists.  I seem to get a lot of bad rentals so thumbs up!
wow! what a story. The movie was great and I would recommend it to everyone. It makes  one realize how easily a child can be taken.
The movie leads you down a few paths that seem to make sense regarding "who done it' but it is a total surprise at the end!!  Perfect mystery and keeps you engaged.

Young parents Keller and Grace Dover walk over to the suburban home of Franklin and Nancy Birch in the November cold for a Thanksgiving Dinner involving neighbours, laughter and bad trumpet playing (Hugh Jackman, Maria Bello, Terence Howard and Viola Davis). Their respective daughters of 7 and 6 Anna and Eliza happily play upstairs with a pet while the adults below drink and reminisce. That is until both children go outside to play - and unaccompanied - addle up to the back of a muddied RV parked suspiciously by the kerb in broad daylight...

Although I thoroughly despise material that uses children being hurt as entertainment - "Prisoners" beats the pants off so many supposed thrillers because it reeks of intelligence (a fantastic and clever script) and has a cast that emotionally rivets you to the screen every second they're up there. It's also prepared to be silent - ordinary even - thereby making some scenes disturbingly close to how real life actually is. It's unnerving, creepy and stomach churning in places too (there are monsters out there).

In order for this to work you need major league actors - and lots of them - and right down to a repentant Paedophile Priest - even the small parts are perfectly cast. Hugh Jackman plays Keller Dover - a redecorator/builder and a 'prepare for the worst' deer-shooting survivalist - while his wife Grace believes she'll and her family will be 'safe' with him. Mild-mannered neighbours and friends Franklin and Nancy Birch have the opposite dynamic - the wife is the boss while her husband is more reflective.  But when a local simpleton Alex Jones is found singing in the front seat of the squalid RV and arrested but won't talk - both sets of parents have their patience and nerves tested. Frustrated by the cops lack of progress and working to the letter of the law - and with the days passing and time running out for their abducted daughters - Alpha Male Keller decides to take matters into his own hands...

Into this emotional cauldron comes Detective Loki who's solved every case he's ever been given. He may at times seem too detached from the parent's pain and rage - but he's a man who spots things and sees through the lies in people (a mesmerizing Jake Gyllenhaal). Obsessive yet law-abiding - he instinctively feels that spaced out Alex Jones who can't say much but can still drive an RV easily - is lying - sickly concealing the whereabouts of the girls and enjoying the cat and mouse game too (an Oscar performance yet again from Paul Dano - the preacher in "There Will Be Blood"). But is he? And what about his heart-broken mother (subtle brilliance from Melissa Leo) who has defended this social outcast all her life - despite her religion-obsessed husband leaving years back and abandoning them both. Keller even goes after her. In the meantime Grace Dover (a ragged looking Maria Bello) simply breaks at the enormity of her child being lost - while the stoical Nancy folds her arms, grits her teeth and reconciles herself to what both fathers must do - go over demarcation lines you really shouldn't cross...

The genius of Aaron Guzikowski's script and Dennis Villeneuve's Direction is that one whole hour in - and you're absolutely none the wiser as to who is the bad guy and who isn't. And it has to be said that some of the violence is horrible and cringing. But what keeps you watching is the sheer visceral power of the actors. The dance between Jackman and Gyllenhaal is fantastic cinema - both men barely holding on to any humanity or faith as the frustration mounts and suspicions arise (exactly the sick kind of mental torture the abductor wants to inflict on them). And you also sit there questioning just how far a determined parent would go to get their child back (abusing a man who may or may not be an innocent).

Special mention has to be made of the picture quality of the BLU RAY. Defaulted to Full Aspect (which fills up the whole screen) - "Prisoners" is starkly gorgeous and truly beautiful throughout. Often without any music - the blunt and stainless steel cold angles ratchet up the tension to unbearable levels (fear of what is happening to the children). It's the Cinematography genius of ROGER DEAKINS ("The Shawshank Redemption" and "True Grit"). Scene after scene is filled with it: casing a house in the pouring rain at night - Jones walking his dog as Keller spies on him from a nearby truck - the decaying body tied to a chair in the basement of a suspect's house - Detective Loki interviewing a sex offender you can't see behind a filthy pane of glass - Loki's tired bulging eyes and unkempt stubble (hasn't slept for days) as he leans forward into a computer monitor scouring the screen for any detail that will help - closing in on the jagged bark of a tree... The framing of everything is the unsung hero of the movie - adding unbelievable depth and genuine unease that serves right up until the superb and clever ending.

There are two Extras - the short "Every Moment Counts" and the more extensive "Powerful Performers" which features enthusiastic interviews with all the principal actors, Director Dennis Villeneuve and Producers Kara Davis and Broderick Johnson. But don't watch "Powerful Performers" before you watch the movie - it rather clumsily gives away far too much in terms of the twisting plot.

The brilliant and unsettling "Prisoners" had my wife and I on the edge of our seats unable to press the pause button to desperately go to the loo. Now that's how you put the 'thrill' in thriller.

Job done I'd say...

This was one of the best movies i have seen in a long time... it showed how angry the parents get and what they are capable of when one of their children has been taken... that doesnt usually happen in a  movie...
What a great movie keeps you wondering. What a surprise at the end. Movie for adults not for children.  Enjoy!!!

As with the movie, Sixth Sense, there are many clues along the way.  In the end, count how many were prisoners (in one way or the other), than add to it those that were prisoners of their mind.  Not boring, and gory.  Not sure it is good for young kids under 12 - no nudity, just a bit too real.
This was an awesome movie.  Makes you think about rushing to judgement in high stress situations.  Really grabs and holds your attention!  Looks like maybe a sequel?

If you like a mystery to unfold slowly and if you do not require all the loose ends tied up, this movie is the one for you.  Like a jigsaw puzzle with a thousand pieces this movie depicts the patience of victims of crimes and the unraveling of their moral fiber when a love on is in danger. Hugh Jackman is excellent as a man searching for his daughter who has gone missing on Thanksgiving Day from a friends gathering. The arduous pace of the movie showcases not the two missing little girls but the effect it has on their families, in particular the father portrayed by Hugh Jackman.  The kidnapping of the two children has unforeseen consequences and the end will leave you scratching your head.  But if you can make it to the finale....and at least feel moved by the plot....you should also try watching "The Vanishing".
shows how lazy cops are and will not do there jobs until it helps them. Did not like the ending at all

I went in with low expectations, and boy was I surprised. Too many movie trailers give away the whole movie, but this one was a rare exception.  The trailers don't reveal much.  You have to watch this movie.

Great story line, great acting, and an ending that you don't see coming. The movie draws you in and keeps you asking yourself what you'd do under the same circumstances.  I don't say this about many movies, but this is a must see.

Watch it with someone, so you can have a discussion about it afterward.

Prisoners is a great movie that I recommend to everybody.  It's a slow movie, but grabs you and doesn't let you go.  The very ending cuts off where you don't want it to, but all in all this is a great suspenseful thriller.  I highly recommend buying it or renting it.

If you have children then you can understand the pain these families and the officer investigating the missing children are going through.  No one knows who to believe or who to trust, and just when you think you have an ideal of what is going on, you get hit with another possibility of the crime in question.  Hugh Jackman, Terrance Howard and the other stars of this film do an outstanding job of showing the pain a victims family goes through along with a police officer who really cares about the case when a loved one is missing.  The pain is even greater when it is a young child, so imagine how you would feel when you find out it is two children missing.
This movie will definately make you hold your children closer and never let them out of your sight.  Great movie that didn't get near enough play time at the theaters. One I would definately recommend for viewing.
Gripping. Had me on the edge. Great performances by all the actors. Makes you think how far will you go to protect your family.
The movie was good but it dragged a lot.  I originally bought the movie because I love to watch Terrance Howard on the big screen.  But I must admit, Hugh Jackman played his part well.

Very suspenseful, compelling story, excellent acting. I don't normally like scary movies but watched this because my brother wanted to. I'm glad I saw it. Probably not something a parent would want to watch though as it deals with child abduction.
Great movie all the twists and turns in this movie will keep you guessing close to the end. Very dark movie.
Very good movie!  Keeps you on the edge of your seat all the way until the end...  This movie needed to be 15 minutes longer.  Made me wonder if Hugh Jackman had to leave this movie early.

If you like to sit through a drag of a movie make sure to run and order this! It goes on and on and on and on and on.....Tormented director waste of two of our best actors with a terrible ending. Not sure why some directors think we have to live in their nightmare. I turned this off after about 2/3 done!

I rated this a five because of the intensity of the film. The parents were sharing in the loss of their children and the people that were involved were right under their noses. I thought it was very interesting that the woman that was supposed to be the adopted mother was the main kidnapper. I did not like how it ended I wanted the father to had been found. I would recommend this movie to all parents and parents -to - be.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

Rating: 3.5 out of 5.0

Canadian director Denis Villeneuve is back with another densely plotted movie with 'Prisoners'. His 2011 'Incendies' was interesting but ultimately full of too many scenes which forced the viewer to suspend one's disbelief, one too many times. 'Prisoners' also has some questionable plot points but it's eminently more entertaining than Incendies.

Villeneuve proffers up an interesting protagonist, Keller Dover (played by an intense Hugh Jackman), a survivalist type, who has no compunctions about teaching his son how to shoot a deer, on a hunting trip, depicted at the beginning of the film. While Jackman has a lot to work with depicting the hot-head Keller, Terrence Howard has little to do playing Franklin Birch, Keller's exact opposite: a passive (and thinly drawn) middle class black professional. The break into Act II occurs when Keller's and Birch's daughters are abducted after disappearing from the Birch family home.

Since an RV was parked right near where the girls disappeared, the driver ends up as the number one suspect. The police soon track the driver down at a rest stop and he tries to escape by eluding a police blockade with his RV. The driver turns out to be Alex Jones, who on the surface appears to be mentally feeble. When Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) can find no evidence linking Alex to the girls' abduction and concludes he doesn't have the mental capacity to kidnap the girls, he's forced to release him, and allow him to return to the residence of Holly Jones, his aunt, a creepy senior, expertly played by Melissa Leo.

A good deal of 'Prisoners' revolves around Keller's abduction and subsequent imprisonment of Alex, who he believes knows where the kidnapped girls are. Keller insists that Alex told him "they didn't cry until I left them," when Keller tries to choke him at the time he's released by the police, in front of a multitude of TV news reporters (no one else hears what Alex says to Keller).

Before discussing the issue of Alex's refusal to talk, there are two red herrings in the plot, designed to throw you off track. Both involve Detective Loki's interaction with two suspects. The first is a priest who's on parole for a sex crime--out of the blue Loki finds a bound, deceased man in the priest's basement. The priest claims that he was forced to kill the man after he revealed (during confession) that he was a serial killer, who would kill again. Later, Loki chases after a suspicious man seen at a vigil for the missing girls, in front of the Birch's home. He turns out to be a wannabe serial killer, Taylor, who breaks into the family houses of real serial killer's victims and steals their clothes. Loki, who supposedly has solved all of his cases, blows this one, after Taylor grabs one of Loki's deputy's guns and shoots himself in the mouth.

Even if you believe in both these incredible turn of events, one is hard pressed to believe in the film's main premise--that Alex would refuse to talk, despite being tortured for days by Keller. SUPER SPOILERS AHEAD. One of the arguments that Alex doesn't talk is because he is mentally handicapped. But that's debunked by the points Keller raises--he knew about the girls and told Keller; he tried to escape from the police in his RV and had a driver's license and was able to drive.

Another reason (which seems to be suggested by the filmmakers) is that he's under the spell of Aunt Holly and is either a) afraid of her, b) evil like her, or c) both. He seemingly is given a free pass at film's end, despite Keller's statement that he confessed that he basically knew where the girls were (the free pass may be due to the fact that Keller's credibility was completely suspect, by breaking the law by abducting him). Still, while possible, I still think it's unlikely that Alex would never have turned against the old lady. Think of the child abduction case of Steven Stayner. He was imprisoned for seven years but when given the opportunity, he escaped and saved a newly abducted child. Alex was the first child abducted by Holly and her husband and the filmmakers would like us to believe he was psychologically beholden to his captor. But in real life, the Stayner case proves the opposite. I would like to think the desire for freedom would still burn in Alex's breast and his abduction by Keller would have been the perfect opportunity for him to spill the beans about his aunt. By confessing, he's smart enough to know that Aunt Holly would immediately be taken into custody and he would not have to be afraid of her anymore.

Prisoners represents a critique of those who embrace the survivalist mentality and act as vigilantes. We expect Keller to save his daughter but actually Detective Loki does so after racing to the hospital and saving Keller's daughter from poisoning (Loki's big car race is not that exciting, since the outcome is pretty much expected). Instead, Keller underestimates Holly who turns out to be responsible for the girls' abduction as well as numerous other serial killings. Keller ends up in that hole and my interpretation of the abrupt (but clever) ending, is that he WILL rescue Keller, and let him face the music.

'Prisoners' indeed will drag you into its electrically-charged story and keep you at the edge of your seat to the end. The supporting players, those who play the wives and children of Keller and Franklin, do quite well, but are saddled by underdeveloped parts. Ultimately, you will have to overlook the red herrings and the main premise that the feeble (or perhaps not so feeble) Alex, will not crack under torture. I prefer to believe that he would, as most people would in that situation.
Two words: Unbelievably boring! The movie dragged on and on, getting nowhere. They could have easily made the runtime at least 30 minutes shorter!
twisted tale of child kidnapping and the parents and detective dealing with the disappearance very violent and bloody at times

After watching Prisoners my reactions was simply, "Wow!  It was an exhausting thrill ride that constantly forced you to asked yourself, "What if it was you?" , "What if it was your child?"  The answer to that question can leave you a little breathless... and maybe even frightened of your own reaction to the inherit desire to protect your children.  I must mention that there are some scenes that are intensely difficult to watch... you are basically seeing a man being tortured.  I am not one for gratuitous violence, but I can honestly say that I don't believe the violence in this film was gratuitous.  It was disgusting and painful, but it was far from disingenuous.

The entire time that Hugh Jackman's character, Keller Dover, is torturing who he is absolutely certain has something to do with his missing daughter - Jackman plays crazy-obsessive so well that you begin to ask yourself, "Did this guy really do it, or is Keller torturing the wrong man?"  Especially when the tortured man whispers, "Help me," to Nancy Birch (the mother of the other missing daughter; and supremely played by Viola Davis).

It is a very intense movie.  The writer (Aaron Guzikowski) and director (Denis Villeneuve) plotted out such a well-structured story, with actors who are incredibly believable.  There isn't a parental reaction that you can't empathize with:  Keller Dover/Hugh Jackman's obsessive need to defend and protect.  Franklin Birch/Terrence Howard willingness to find his daughter, but constantly questioning his own morality at torturing another human being.  Nancy Birch/Viola Davis just wants her daughter back; she supports Jackman's actions if there is even the slightest possibility of getting their children back.  Grace Dover/Maria Bello who is comatose with grief, but propels the story along for the detective (my favorite part of the movie was Jake Gyllenhaal).

And then there's Jake Gyllenhaal character Detective Loki; who is just as obsessed with finding the missing girls as Jackman, but he doesn't lose sight of the law or his place in the justice system.  As I said, this was a masterfully crafted movie.  It used the plot and characters to move it along and tell the story.  When was the last time that happened in a movie?  There is no over the top CG, just great acting and superb story telling.  I loved it!

This is the kind of movie where you have to pay attention because everything is a clue.  As I watched Jake Gyllenhaal interview Mrs. Millard, I kept thinking "how does a child abduction over ten years old have anything to do with the suspect who barely looks twenty?" ... but it was an integral part of discovering the culprit.

Also, Ive seen some reviews mention the language/cursing and I couldn't help but think, this is a movie about a man who decides to torture another human being who may or may not have had anything to do with his daughters abduction, and the one thing that bothered you is the cursing really??

Watch this movie, but I don't recommend this on a family movie night (too intense for the kiddies).  Prepare to yell at the TV (especially at the incredible ending), and cringe with frustration and hope.  I hope more movies rely on plot and characters.  Yes, please more like this!

With zero expectations for this movie, it just blew me away on every level. I had only known it was some sort of revenge thriller involving a kidnapping. So while that is a sparse summary of the plot, it fails to capture the magnitude, gravitas, and power of this film.

This movie is not so easy to watch. From the actors' many fine performances to its somber tone, there is a heavy and real sense of dread that is likely off-putting for more sensitive viewers. You may have seen hundreds of films and shows where the heroes' lives are in peril, but they are all so cozy and trite by comparison. This film is the very rare exception where you become truly immersed in the story and empathize with its various gut-wrenching emotions of fear, doubt, sanity and rage. I honestly can't remember the last time I cared so much about a group of characters. From the outset, it's obvious that this is a serious and adult movie, one where nobody is safe, and a happy ending is hardly guaranteed after so many clever turns in the story. There is a darkness throughout even the heroes which can qualify the film as a neo-noir, despite its gloomy Northern country setting.

There are many other superb elements to this movie beyond its engaging plot. The film looks absolutely amazing thanks to multi-Oscar-nominated cinematographer Roger Deakins, who's also shot Shawshank and a half-dozen of the Coen brothers' films. The score is perfectly simple but wonderful. The actors all give astoundingly heartfelt performances too.

If you can handle this movie's intensity, it will haunt you with its elegance. This is one of the finest mystery/thrillers made of recent years due to the powerful heart which accompanies the heady procedural.
