Prisoners (Denis Villeneuve, 2013)

I'll be up front with you: I am writing the first sentences of this review, which I expect will be a very long one, without knowing what rating I will actually be giving Prisoners. I believe that somewhere over the course of the thousands of reviews I have written (Amazon is home to over six thousand of them as of this writing, on October 5, 2013, and I had been reviewing steadily for longer before I started posting there than I have been since I started, so you can do the math...) that has probably happened before...but I can't remember it, if it has. I have a great deal to mull over before figuring that out, I think. I liked it, overall; there is a great deal to like about it. It is surprisingly well-paced for having come out of a film culture where directors are actively encouraged to make their films about half as long as this one (this is the only film I have seen made in the last fifteen years that is this long that is not either (a) a musical, (b) a Shah Rukh Khan vehicle, or (c ) both of the above), it is unflinching in its examination of violence, its script is intelligent and multi-layered (though it does overplay its hand now and again), it is impeccably-cast, and I could keep going like this all night without really digging into the film at all. But it is not perfect, and while I admit I finished watching it less than an hour and a half before I am writing the opening words of this review, the more I think about the nagging questions I walked out of the theater with, the more they nag at me. Time will tell (and probably will, before I finish writing this review, which will probably be a few weeks from nowif I follow standard operating procedure with it, anyway) if they continue to nag, but the biggest thing that bothered me, and my first impression is that much of this comes from Jake Gyllenhaal being one of the male leads, is that I saw a lot of Zodiac in this movie. I also saw a lot of Snowtown, which is harder to explain away. That made some of what unfolded on the screen before me more predictable than, I think, it should have been; almost certainly more than screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski (Contraband) intended. But we shall see after I keep mulling it over; I'm going to go do some more of that right now.

Plot: Keller Dover (X-Men's Hugh Jackman) and Frankin Burch (Hustle and Flow's Terrence Howard) are friends in the suburbs. They get together for Thanksgiving; their daughters go out, saying they're heading over to the other house to do whatever it is that preteen girls do away form the prying eyes of their parents. They never make it. Suspicion is immediately cast on a broken-down old camper that has been seen in the area; when the police track it down in the dark corner of a convenience store parking lot, they find its driver to be young mentally-challenged Alex Jones (The Good Heart's Paul Dano). The police, in the form of one Detective Loki (The Day After Tomorrow's Jake Gyllenhaal), interrogate Jones, but do not have enough evidence to go anywhere with it; he is ultimately released, leading Dover to take matters into his own hands. Initially, Burch goes along with Dover's plan for extracting information, but the longer things go one, the more Dover pulls away not only from Burch, but from the rest of his life. Eventually, people start noticing that Alex has gone missing, and Detective Loki's focus hones in on Dover.

And now back to my initial paragraph, which I wrote five months before this one. About 80% of this movie is phenomenal, a thought-provoking journey into the motivations and actions of people who are driven to desperation. The other 20% feels as if it were tacked on for a commercial audience who would not be satisfied with that and needed some sort of conventional mystery to resolve. It's trite, relies on plot twists you've seen in half a hundred other movies of its ilk, and while it is as well-presented as the rest of the moviethese are all fine actors turning in fine performances, Villeneuve (Incendies) certainly knows his way around a camera, and  Roger Deakins was nominated for an Oscar for his chilling cinematography (he lost to, of course, Gravity)it still feels kind of like the old Irving Pichel trick of hey, we finished shooting a week early and have some extra stock, let's make another movie!...except this time they stitched the two together, and the graft didn't quite take. The straight mystery at the end is watchable, but in juxtaposition to the drama/thriller/horror film that comes before it, it pales. Should you see it? Absolutely. Is it, as IMDB would have us believe as I am writing this in March 2014, one of the 250 best movies ever made (it is sitting at #249)? Not on your life. ***

Two young girls are abducted after a Thanksgiving meal where their two families are celebrating in the home of one of them.  The girls have wandered outside to play and go unnoticed for some time while the families enjoy one another's company.  Eventually, people begin to notice their absence and then, very quickly, panic sets in and the two fathers (Hugh Jackman and Terrence Howard) run off to look for them.  In the meantime Jackman's son remembers that, earlier, the girls were fascinated by a motorhome parked a little way down the street when they had gone out prior to dinner.  He tells his father and they go to look for the motorhome, which is now gone.

Enter the police, primarily in the form of Jake Gyllenhaal, who quickly locate the motorhome and its sole occupant and bring him into custody.  However, when they try to interrogate him they find that he has the mental age of a 10 year old and are forced to release him after a forensic search shows no physical evidence of the missing girls in the vehicle.

This incenses Jackman's character who decides to take matters into his own hands with grim consequences!  This film examines the obvious toll on all the members of a family whose child has been abducted and we witness the harrowing aftermath for all concerned as the tragedy unfolds before our eyes.  The movie seems more to have echoes of `Dead Zone' rather than `Taken', as it scrutinizes the almost Gothic weirdness of small town America beneath the Norman Rockwell homespun, 'apple pie' type images that we are often fed.

And it's all the more disturbing in the wake of the recent revelations, in Austria, America and elsewhere of kidnappings, imprisonment and even the enslavement of abducted children who seem simply to disappear into thin air and the twisted logic of the individuals who perpetrate this evil, often seeking to mitigate their actions in religious terms!

The whole cast puts in very convincing performances and this, together with an intelligent script, makes for horribly compelling viewing but one you probably won't want to repeat any time soon!

If you have children, or if you are attached to a niece or nephew, then PRISONERS will make you quake in your boots from start to finish. It takes the most terrifying idea that a parent has, your child being abducted, and tosses it about in a fashion unseen before on screen. Is that a good thing? Yes.

The film opens with two families living in the same neighborhood getting together for Thanksgiving. One is Keller and Grace Dover (Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello), the other Franklin and Nancy Birch (Terence Howard and Viola Davis). After dinner the Dover's daughter wants to run home with the Birch's daughter to look for a whistle she can't find. Terror soon follows.

The two girls can't be found and the older kids they were supposed to ask go with them never knew that they left. From an earlier walk Dover's son remembered an RV parked down the road that his sister tried to climb. A manhunt follows with everyone searching for the girls and that RV.

As it so happens Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhall) gets the call about a sighting of the RV. He gets to the scene only to have the driver speed into a tree and then be captured. What they find is a young man named Alex Jones (Paul Dano) with some mental issues who either can't or won't answer their questions. Keller can't believe the police are as helpless as he is when it comes to finding answers and holds them accountable.

The search continues and eventually Jones is released. Keller confronts him in the parking lot and Jones whispers something to him that makes Keller believe he knows what happened to the girls. Intent on finding his daughter, even if the police have their hands tied with legalities, Keller kidnaps Jones and takes him to an abandoned apartment building he owns. With the reluctant help of Franklin he systematically tortures Jones to get information. It's brutal but not over done considering what's on the screen these days.

As Keller seeks information his way Det. Loki follows clues of his own. With a record of solving every case he's been assigned he doggedly pursues each lead that comes his way. Some go nowhere but a few turn up a suspect other than Jones, one who turns up at a candle light vigil for the two girls and who escapes Loki when he pursues him on foot. This doesn't stop him from continuing his search as well as his looking at Keller as a possible suspect as well.

Do they find the girls? Are they still alive? And just who really kidnapped them if anyone? If you want to know what happens rent or buy the movie, don't expect me to give it away. The twists and turns in this plot bounce back and forth more than Mullholland Drive if it were ice covered and foggy. The movie does a great job of making you think one way then convincing you that you should look another only to toss in a third concept before making you think you were right to begin with. Got that? Well that's the sort of back and forth I'm talking about. In the end everything fits in place and the result is an ending that makes sense. I won't say you'll be happy with it, but it makes sense.

As seems to be the case with many films these days there isn't a bad performance on screen here. Jackman and Gyllenhall take center stage when it comes to outstanding performances, both exercising their acting muscles by playing parts different than we've seen them in before. Howard is given far too small a part to play here but does it well. Bello and Davis feel more like supporting roles than leads here and that's a shame. Dano once more plays that misunderstood character and does a fine job.

THE PRISONERS (2013) is basically well acted by both its stars (Hugh Jackman and Jake Gylllenhaal) and its supporting cast (Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, Viola Davis, and Paul Dano), BUT from the very outset its IMPLAUSIBLE SCREENPLAY goes from one huge plot hole to another.

Following the opening scene in which a teenage boy is forced to shoot a deer by his RW survivalist father (played by Hugh Jackman), we see fresh venison being taken to the survivalist's BEST FRIEND'S big house for a two-family dinner ... after everyone in each family has hugged and kissed everyone else. Amazingly, and without any explanation, Jackman's wife and son and little daughter are ALL BEST FRIENDS with this other family, which just happens to be the only black family shown in the semi-rural small town in the entire movie. Given my own seven-decade experience of racism in America in New England, in the South, in the Midwest, and in the Northwest, I found this incredible as a story premise.

HERE BE A FEW SPOILERS - The first two of four prisoners referred to by the title are the two young daughters of Jackman and Howard (one white; one black) who within a very short time are kidnapped in broad daylight. (Later, two adults are held as prisoners by people NOT associated with the police.) Within minutes of the kidnapping, however, a super detective (played by Jake Gyllenhaal) apprehends a suspect, a retarded young man (Paul Dano), who seems to have been living with his elderly aunt, but (apparently) the police have the wrong man in custody and have to release him. This does NOT sit well with Hugh Jackman's macho, take-charge self-image: he decides to do some "enhanced interrogation" of his own, with the very reluctant help of his beloved black buddy (Terrence Howard). Prolonged GRAPHIC TORTURE SCENES ensue.

HERE BE A FEW MORE SPOILERS - Meanwhile Det. Gyllenhaal, who has never taken on a case without solving it, begins to suspect that a SERIAL KILLER is involved and tracks down an alternative suspect who has more than a few screws loose ... and while engaged in his own "enhanced interrogation," Det. G. goofs up and brings about the death of that new suspect.

BUT WAIT, IT GETS WILDER - Just when there seems to be a dead end, as LUCK would have it, the little black girl CONVENIENTLY is able to escape her captor and reunite with her family! And somehow she puts Hugh Jackman on to a new trail ... which has a very bad outcome for him - besides him being shot. (At this point the audience knows for certain WHO the perverted serial killer is - and that "answer" is LITERALLY unbelievable.)

But of course there is MORE to come. Det. Gyllenhaal also discovers who that pervert is, and he too is shot (in the head) but keeps on ticking and SAVES not one but TWO prisoners of the pervert ... but not (tweet) at the same time (tweet).

The audience (tweet) expects Det. Gyllenhaal (who has NOT been suspended for causing the death of a suspect in custody and who immediately is released from the hospital and NOT kept under observation) to achieve some sort of additional unbelievable SUCCESS despite his head wound (tweet), and he (tweet) does so ... in exactly the (tweet) way that any eight-year-old who is halfway paying attention to this film will (tweet) easily (tweet) guess fifteen minutes before it (tweet, tweet) ends.

 If I were giving this film a letter grade, in my judgment it deserves a "D-". A very good cast is almost TOTALLY WASTED here.

This is an intense movie within the first few minutes. It moves relatively slowly with not a lot of action but it's difficult to take your eyes away from the tremendous performances from a talented cast.

Hugh Jackman is riveting. The desperate father doing everything he can to find his daughter, even break the law. His performance reminded me a little of Mel Gibson's great performance in "Ransom" which featured a similar theme of the kidnapped child. Jackman's interplay with Gyllenhaal is powerful particularly in what is not said between them.

Melissa Leo, Viola Davis, Terence Howard, Maria Belo and Paul Dano all play excellent support roles.

It's quite a long movie (2.5 hours) but the time passes before you know it.

Highly recommended.

I saw this on the recommendation of a friend/co-worker.  While the climax of the movie seems a bit forced, and the attempt by the filmmakers to make the plot like the labyrinth that holds the key to the kidnapped girls' location begins to get a bit tiresome, what sticks with me are the performances.  I've never been a huge fan of Hugh Jackman, but he more than rises to the occasion here as the obsessed father whose own suppressed demons begin to resurface.  It's a terrifying and sensitive performance that finally convinced me of his talent.  Paul Dano, who first caught my attention for his brilliance in "There Will Be Blood," is pitiable as the mentally challenged young man who seems like the prime suspect.  His torture as the hands of Jackman's character happens mostly off-screen (thankfully), but he remains a sad, lost, sympathetic figure even when he's clearly hiding something.  My favorite performance, though, is Jake Gyllenhaal as the taciturn Det. Loki.  The "defective detective" has become a clich in modern procedural drama, but what makes Loki an intriguing character are the qualities only hinted at: the tattoos, the nerdy/hipster clothes and hair, the Freemasons ring, the involuntary blinking especially when stressed.  These all hint at a dark past that is never dragged into the spotlight and add to the character's mystery.  When Loki finally explodes, it's as if he's releasing everything he's repressed since before the events of this movie.  Brilliant acting and super backstory building by Gyllanhaal, who has impressed me since "Donnie Darko."

Unfortunately, other terrific actors get short shrift due to the trio of outstanding performances already mentioned.  Terrance Howard in particular is tragically underserved in his role as Jackman's friend and attempted voice of consciousness.  Viola Davis is onscreen even less, and poor Maria Bello is given almost nothing to do.  With the almost two-and-a-half running time, more insight into the grieving/coping of the mothers could have been powerful, but we don't get to see much of it.  Watch this for Jackman, Gyllenhaal, and Dano--their performances will stay wit you.

Great film, good cast, very satisfied by this item.

For cinema fans who are drawn to the dark, bleak side of movies, this is for you. We have a strong ensemble cast in this crime thriller, headed by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal (both excellent, although Jake steals the show for me), and a mysterious case of child abduction that keeps us guessing. Overall, a powerful and harrowing drama. This one may linger with you afterwards, with its sinister and gloomy vibe.

I am puzzled that only the cinematography got nominated for an Oscar this year. No director, no score, no Gyllenhaal, no Jackman, no supporting players, no editing.

I love a film in which I can't guess who the culprit is until the very end, and Prisoners actually surprised me.  Hugh Jackman really showed his range in this movie.  Viola Davis, Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, Melissa Leo and Paul Dano as the mentally challenged man who was the main suspect in the kidnapping were brilliant.  The only gripe I have is (Don't read any further if you haven't seen the film) SPOILER ALERT*** why couldn't the filmmakers spare 20 more seconds at the end to show us whether or not Hugh Jackman's character survived???  Jake Gyllenhaal's cop character heard a faint noise and then the movie faded to black!  Filmmakers, that kind of device is very frustrating to your audience.

I love Hugh jackman and jake gyllenhall (sp) and this movie was suspenseful and kept me on my seat. I'm not sure how I feel about the ending, some mixed feelings.

I thought the movie was pretty good. I wasn't crazy about the way it ended, with the dad in the hole. I would have liked to see how things turned out.
I could see how a parent would feel if that happened to their child, but the dad sure went over the top.

I loved this movie so much I watched it twice. I don't understand the negative ratings at all. I've been a movie buff all my life and know when a bad movie is around...this one is truly great. So give it a watch and be surprised at the end.
The movie had an excellent plot and  Hugh Jackman did an Oscar worthy job of acting. Kept me guessing until the very end.

This is by no means a "Slasher" film, but is definitely filled with suspense, multiple late-breaking twists and a macabre mood overall.  Very weird but believable characters abound. Although there may be a couple of logical flaws, they are minor and really don't detract from the fine acting and unusual plot.  The dramatic content is superior with a rich tonal overlay that brings to mind the excellent television series, "The Killing" (Season 1).
it was just a really good movie, it's hard to find a really good movie that'll keep your attention, and this one did.

One of my favorite movies - after watching it with my fianc, I watched it again the next day with my dad before the rental expired. Every time I thought I figured it out, the story would take a twist, and I'd second guess myself. A good intellectual movie with just enough psychological thrill, and tons of suspense

This film has received much acclaim from critics and has even made it to the top of best-film lists. I was excited to finally watch it and  when I was 20-30 minutes into the film, I could already tell that I was not going to enjoy the rest of it. Don't get me wrong, the performances by everyone were great. However, there were a few things that happened throughout the movie that took me out of the viewing experience.

Things that were *literally* incredible. Some events and actions were just too unrealistic for me. I would name some examples, but I don't want to add any spoilers to this review. I felt that many of the scenes were over-acted for dramatic effect. I found the gratuity of these scenes to be ridiculous and even laughable. I was just bored and uninterested. The use of red herrings and Macguffins made for an interesting story, but I felt that they couldn't hold the movie together. I am so disappointed in this film and would actually like a refund for my digital rental. If you want to see a similar film involving a dark story with mystery, suspense, and action, I recommend The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (American version).

I don't recommend spending your 153 minutes on this film.

Ok, now that my son told me how much he liked this movie (he's 14), I told him, after I watched it, he should check out the classic "Silence of the Lambs".  I may be the only one- but this movie reminded me slightly of that other one which engages with the characters in their individual and so committed effort to conquer the bad and find justice after all.
We really enjoyed this story along with the plot twist. The movie was very well acted by an exceptional cast, special mention for Gyllenhaal.
Smart, scary, suspenseful and thrilling. This movie had it all. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Brilliant performances from jake and hugh.

This film was unnecessarily violent and melodramatic. Hugh Jackman obviously wants to move to more dramatic, heavyweight roles and he is talented enough to do so. But this scrip was the wrong choice to begin that transition. His character bordered on the hysterical and psychotic in his search for his kidnapped daughter--was the script, the director, or Jackman himself responsible for this portrayal? We'll never know. But nothing toned down the performance, no nuance, no real examination of the character's background, his relationship with his daughter, nothing to explain the explosive personality beyond the obvious--my daughter has been kidnapped. We needed background scenes. The character was as cold-blooded and as unexplored as the psyche of the kidnapper. Next time around Jackman should look for a character with nuance, control, intensity; one the audience can identify with in some way. This performance, this film left me dead in the water.
I love the actors in this movie, and even the subject matter.  Somehow, the two didn't work together.  This was a dark and overly gruesome movie.
It was a good movie.  The twist at the end was a little confusing.  Overall I enjoyed the movie a great deal.

Great movie depicting every parent's nightmare, but it has a few plot twists that keep it from being predictable.  The lead actor gives an outstanding performance playing a passionate father who's just trying to do whatever he feels is necessary to protect his daughter.

The premise is engaging. Two cute kid girls go missing during a Thanksgiving dinner between neighbors. The obvious fear is a kidnapping. And if that's the case, they'll probably be raped and killed. Such an outcome could make for a mighty poignant movie. But writer Aaron Guzikowski and director Denis Villeneuve would rather cater to the morals of its audience, so blunt realism is overshadowed by silly unlikelihoods, more and more as the story goes on. The actions of Keller Dover, the father of one of the young daughters, are particularly outrageous.

marcellee.com
It was a great movie with a troubling storyline.  It was on the verge of morbid, yet exciting and suspenseful.

I enjoyed this movie. Great story line. I could feel Hugh Jackman  pain & determined to find their children. It was a long movie. But he kept me in suspense the whole entire movie. This movie let me & others know that there are still people in this world that strive off of hurting children. So you truly have too be care who leave with children

Break out the Prozac and Xanax. The movie is depressing and upsetting. There is no moral to the story. Really nothing to learn. You may like that kind of movie. It's well made. Having small children this was a difficult movie to watch for me. My stomach was in knots for most of the movie. I really believe this to be one of Hugh Jackman's best films. I was expecting much less from him, but I was pleasantly and found his portrayal really believable.

I would say that this is even more nightmarish than SOTL .  Not haunted house scary but reminds me of a long nightmarish dream that you wake up from rattled and exhausted.  Like SOTL it starts to have spiritual undertoe of something good trying to get out .  There is a glimmer of hope.  For most of the film it seems like the movie doesnt care about its inhabitants.  Everyone is suffering or evil or both.  Its a good movie just not a fun movie.  I am not sure i could watch it again but i definitely felt like I experienced something .
in fact, next day i rewound certain parts of the movie to doublecheck the clues!  I enjoyed this movie -

Well, this movie didn't turn out to be what I expected it to be.  My bad.  I must not have really read the plot line.  But it is a good move. For a film that is over two and a half hours long, there are so many plot holes in Prisoners Im almost tempted to wish that it was three hours in length, and then again, maybe I just wish that it had never been made.  Watching the film in the first place took inner strength, since the subject matter is one that I have a very strong reaction to, but I expected to at least be rewarded with a thought provoking film that tested my inner calm but delivered a strong impact.

Instead, I was left with confusion, frustration and indifference.

Honestly, it was like screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski and director Denis Villeneuve thought that if you throw enough unnecessary details into a pot and stir them, the audience won't notice the plot holes because theyll be as distracted as Detective Loki by a bunch of stuff that makes no sense and means absolutely nothing.

The premise of Prisoners is a relatively simple one.  The Dovers and the Birchs are neighbors and friends.  They hang out a lot, apparently.  One day, while they are socializing at the Birch residence, their young daughters leave to find a lost whistle and wind up missing.  They search to no avail and then the police are brought in and despite having a lead, there is nothing solid and no real evidence that they can get their hands on and Keller Dover soon feels the need to take matters into his own hand.  In a move that many fathers in this position would contemplate but never actually act out, Keller kidnaps the prime suspect, locks him in an abandoned building, and tortures him for answers he won't divulge.  Keller just KNOWS that this young man (who is obviously mentally handicapped) has the answers to where these little girls are and so he continues to beat and torture him despite getting nothing out of him.  The Birch family becomes involved, but they remain at a distance (or at least as much as possible).  In the meantime, Detective Loki becomes consumed with unraveling the mystery of these vanished girls and follows up on the few leads he gets only to find himself preoccupied by the suspicious activity of Keller himself.

As the days tick by, the prospect of finding these girls alive grows slim.

I have SO MANY issues with this film that discussing them would almost take an entire day, but Ill try and just sputter.  It really all boils down to a film about complete incompetence.  First off, these parents are kind of dense.  You let your little girls leave the house to wander down the street in search of a whistle, and despite the fact that you make it clear you never let them wander off alone you forget they ever left until hours have gone by, even with the knowledge of a creepy van on the street?  That doesnt make sense to me at all.  Be attentive!  Next, Loki seems to be the ONLY person on the police team to be remotely interested in seeing these girls reunited with their families.  Despite having a suspect, they drop the ball and don't even tail him, allowing him to be kidnapped and have the police be none the wiser.  Next, you have a suspect with a creepy van parked outside of his Aunts home, and she admits that he does that all the time, and yet you don't investigate her house or her property for clues?  How is that?  Shouldnt that have been the FIRST thing you did, even if you didn't suspect her of anything?  Then you have Keller, who does what every man in that situation is thinking, and yet you allow yourself to become a complete monster by brutally assaulting a man who is three shades away from going full retard?  I mean, how does that solve anything?  This is an issue with me because you basically have a man beating on a child to get answers as to what he supposedly did with a child.  Maybe this is the moral dilemma we are supposed to face, but the film seems so uninterested in making Keller anything more than the savior of his children.

Incompetence, both in character and in filmmaking.

But lets get into that incompetent filmmaking for a minute.  What about all those details that are all over the place?  You can spin your wheels all you want and color in every surface and draw those mazes all over the place, but at the end of the day it all feels like a waste of time.  Lets have this creepy guy buy kids clothes and sneak into the victims homes that so the audience will think he had something to do with it only to have him off himself before he explains anything to anyone and then just drop it without really explaining anything (yes, I know who he wasbut what was he doing in the Dover and Birch residence?).  Lets throw mazes all over the walls and then shows a flashback with a book of mazes and a creepy message and thennot explain what the mazes have to do with anything!  Lets give the kidnapper this ridiculous backstory and then never talk about it past a solitary comment.

Lets spend two and a half hours doing absolutely nothing but giving the impression that we are doing a LOT!

And don't even get me started on the ending.  This is what I mean about these holes in plot that just don't add up.  Keller discovers the truth, but instead of informing the police and rushing to the rescue with Loki, he runs FROM the police and goes there alone, only to dig himself into a very deep hole (literally) and then, when all is said and done it takes quite a bit of time before the police do anything about investigating the area in which the crime took place (once again, wouldnt that be the FIRST thing you did?).

That stupid whistle.

But the ensemble is great, right?  Sort of.  They all work to an extent, but the only one who really does a lot with what hes given is Jake Gyllenhaal.  He actually works to flesh out Loki and his obsessions, while the others tend to give a glossed over variation of a solitary emotion.  Jackman yells and glares and then prays.  Davis cries.  Howard awkwardly holds his mouth in shock and looks like he wants to pee in his pants.  Maria Bello kind of disappears from the whole movie only to reappear as a loon.  Paul Dano doesnt have the chance to do much but look scared and scream.  Melissa Leo gets saddled with a ridiculous character, and while she sells it Im not quite sure I care for what shes selling.

Conceptually, Prisoners had promise.  As a father (of two young girls about the age of the ones kidnapped here), I was not looking forward to watching this.  My biggest fear is something like this.  Abuse is bad enough, but not knowing where and what is happening to your children is the WORST feeling in the world, and I have to admit, I was totally TEAM KELLER for the first half of this film, but Prisoners doesnt know how to develop this concept in a way that feels authentic or even intelligent.  It all just feels so stupid.
The movie was good and the end was a surprise thriller.  During the movie, the middle seems to be slow.  This is a great guy movie.
Very good movie, a thriller, all the pieces all fit together, I have recommended it to many of my friends
Keeps you guessing until the end. Very interesting plot.  As a parent you can put yourself in the character's shoes!
This movie had my attention from beginning to end! Great acting with an even better plot. So if you want to see a really good movie, this is the one.
started the movie late one night and only planned on watching half of it....well it pulled us in and we watched the whole thing.  full of twists and turns
I can imagine being in that position and can totally relate. Fantastic movie. Hits very close to home, loved it!

The story is inconceivable. A bumbling, clueless detective and no FBI? Who are these clowns who try to tell these stories? So if the FBI is not involved, then it must be a tale about a small town, a small area, where everybody knows everybody and everything - included what happened in the past, and yet everybody walks around as if they're half asleep - and then to introduce the hocus pocus about some sedative drug without actually seeing any of it happen previously - makes no sense whatsoever. The concept of everybody being Prisoners is also not fleshed out properly, and the scene at the beginning of the deer in the woods being shot has nothing to do with the rest of the story and completely unnecessary. The film couldn't make up its mind whether it was about Jackman's character or Gyllenhaal's. I've never seen a cop character as clueless and out-dated as this one in this day and age. He doesn't know how to use the computer, he can't see what's right under his nose, and he has no idea who anybody is in his own town! Jackman is over the top as usual, Howard is totally wasted in the film, and everybody else phoned it in. I'm sure the script read better when they agreed to the project, as there were so many scenes that were obviously cut out from the film for time (why were there so many scenes that faded to dark as the most important revelatory moments of drama?). Do not be fooled - it is a stupid film story done very poorly.
The movie pulled at my heart strings and was filled with suspense. It was great! I recommend it to everyone!

I first decided to watch trailer because of the cast of terrific actors.  I wasn not disappointed.  From the moment the girls went missing, the suspense didn't stop.  Anyone with children will hold their breath as this story unfolds.
I didn't know what to expect from this movie but liked the cast overall and the preview gave me an idea that this would be a unique movie.  Loved it from start to finish!
An awesome movie. It shows us just how fast our children can be abducted. And at any age too. There are TOO many sick minded people in this world. Jake did awesome job acting (as usual).
Very good movie!  The plot was very good and it never had you bored.  The actors did great!  Enjoyed this!

NO SPOILER ALERT: I did craft this review in such a way that you might think it contains a spoiler. It's doesn't. You'll have to find your own way to learn how the movie ends.

I like really good suspense movies. "Prisoners" looked dark enough. Good cast, decent ratings, what could go wrong?

"Prisoners" serves up plenty of suspense. It's got a good storyline, if you can follow it ... or stay awake while it meanders down a long and twisted path. It's about madness and mayhem, saints and sinners, the lost and forgotten, the found and forgiven, Nearly each character is a whack job. And Hugh Jackman can really scream in bass.

I'm often disappointed when a movie I want to see is a mere 90 min. I feel cheated. That won't happen again. With "Prisoners," I got what I longed for - a story with some meat behind it. Two and a half hours worth. Yeah!  However, I found myself checking my watch every 15 minutes to see how much longer the torture would go on.

After a very long ride, you want out of this car. You're ready for an ending. Any ending. Near the end, I stopped caring if the children were dead or alive. I just wanted to put a cap on it. When the denouement comes, you'll wake up awash with an emotion: anger. You'll want to kill the screenwriter, the producers, the actors. Ultimately, we are its last victim as the ending we so waited for washes away like a bad roll in the sack, unsatisfied.

I can't recommend it. I don't want you to go through the torture I went through, waiting till all the bodies turn up. Who knows, though, you might like it. Plenty of people did.

Director: Denis Villeneuve.

Writer: Aaron Guzikowski.

Staring: Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Paul Dano, Viola Davis, Terrence Howard, Maria Bello, Melissa Leo and David Dastmalchian.

Running Time: 153 minutes.

Rating: R for Disturbing Violent Content including Torture, and Language throughout.

Let's get this right out of the way for Prisoners: It is not a happy a movie. If you're expecting a good time or to come out with a smile on your face, this is not your type of movie. You would be much better off popping in something like Pacific Rim or seeing if Frozen is still playing where you live. But even if a film is horribly depressing, that doesn't mean you shouldn't watch it if given the chance. Far from it with something like Prisoners, the English language debut of Canadian director Denis Villeneuve (Incendies). While its grueling content and odd plot points may cause some contention with viewers, Prisoners delivers on damn near every cylinder you should expect to see in a good mystery: Excellent performances, a plot that keeps you guessing till the very end, haunting cinematography and some interesting debates on morality and what one would do and how far they would go to save a loved one.

One day, somewhere in Pennsylvania, a small get together with two families is going on. Set sometime around Thanksgiving, the two families The Dovers (Hugh Jackman playing Keller and Maria Bello playing Grace) and The Birches (Viola Davis playing Nacy and Terrence Howard playing Franklin) are having a nice get together. Everybody's laughing, chowing down tasty food, just having a good time together. The teens hang out while the youngsters, Anna Dover and Joy Birch, are off playing around in the neighborhood.

A few hours latter, the two youngest disappear. An investigation is soon kicked into motion and headed by Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) to find out who it is Eventually, the find a suspect in the form of mentally handicapped Alex Jones (Paul Dano). But due to the fact there is a lack of evidence on whether he did it or not, he winds up being released. The father of one of the families, Keller Dover, however, becomes increasingly unstable over the course of the investigation, resorting to his own (brutal) methods to find out if Alex actually did it or not.

So yes, as one can tell from that synopsis up top, Prisoners isn't what one would call a "feel good movie". On top of that, it isn't one that goes by quick. It fully expects you to sit down and watch as it takes you on a long journey of what its like to have a child taken from you. Whether you have or haven't had kids, you feel steeped in the misery and horror of what the parents go through in the film. Hell, the film was originally slapped with an NC-17 rating before it got re-edited with a R. Frankly, after watching the film itself, it doesn't surprise me that it almost got the former.

Another interesting note to make is that in addition to being a Drama-Mystery-Thriller, the film is also a play on morality. Most of the characters never stay clean for long, especially High Jackman's character, who pulls some especially dickish things to find his kid. As seen in the trailers (don't worry; this all happens in the first half hour), he winds up kidnapping Alex to find out where the children are, but what he does will make your stomach churn. Even as the film went as on, I found myself conflicted with his character, wanting him to find his kids but I wished he'd stop being such an ass in trying to find his kid. The film itself and its characters are even asking themselves if what they're doing is justified or not.

What I found interesting about the film is that you never really know who's who or what till the end. For the majority of the film's running time, it keeps you guessing on whether Alex did it or not. Is he playing stupid? Does he genuinely not know what happened to the kids? Was he manipulated into doing what he did? It's like being in a maze, a nightmarish labyrinth from where there is no escape from until the very end.

The film's performances are uniformly excellent, with Hugh Jackman showing us a scary side of his acting abilities that we haven't seen before. His character shows a broad range of anger, ruthlessness and regret. The performance as Dover is so good, it outright makes his iconic Wolverine role look downright pathetic by comparison. I can also safely say that thanks to this role, Jackman's was able to partially redeem himself after being in last year's blunderpiece Movie 43. He's not quite there yet, but I hold him in much higher regard than I did after 43. The rest of the supporting cast also give great performances as well. Jake Gyllenhaal continues to be one of the best actors working today, with an almost equally compelling side role as the determined Detective Loki. One scene in particular that stands out for me with him is when flips out in his office. I won't say what happens in regards to that part in what triggers him, but damn, he really lost it in a big way.

Terrence Howard and Paul Dano bring their goods to the table as well, as does Maria Bello and Viola Davis. Melissa Leo also shows up as Alex Jones' mother, Holly, and while she doesn't have that many scenes in the film, she is compelling enough to keep an admirable presence on-screen. Even the kids who play Joy and Anna (Kyla Drew Simmons and Erin Gerasimovich, respectively) do their roles without some kind of saccharine or sickly-sweet kind of way that one would usually expect from kids in movies.

Shot by famous cinematographer Roger Deakins (Skyfall, No Country For Old Men, The Shawshank Redemption), Prisoners looks unsurprisingly beautiful in its imagery. Damn near every frame looks downright perfect, with scenes that look like they were molded by a paint brush than a camera. Denis and Deakins obviously know what they're doing, and I hope that they collaborate more in the future. Then there's the score by Jhann Jhannsson, who achieves haunting yet minimalist work that help establish the mood of the picture quite excellently.

If there were any problems I had with the film, I'd say it would be some plot elements. There's something that happens to Paul Dano's character in which he ends up disappearing from the public eye and it doesn't really get addressed until the last 30 minutes of the movie. Arguably, due to the investigation of the girls, I can see how their disappearance could be held in higher regard than Dano's but it was still a little something that bothered me.

Then there's how the film handles its clues, foreshadowing and red-herrings, in which it maybe just a little too clever for its own good. It's great to see a film keep its audience guessing all the way through and then pull the rug under their feet when they least expect it, but it felt like the movie was getting a little overly complicated. Not that it was a major hindrance to the film's quality, but I can see how some would be fed up with the plot twists and the loopty loops the film pulls from time to time.

It's a shame that the film was missed at the Oscar season. It was a big contender in the first couple of weeks it came out but due to being swarmed by a mountain of other films (Gravity, 12 Years A Slave, The Wolf of Wall Street), it sadly got overlooked and wound up with only a nom for Best Cinematography. Yet, in spite of that, its more than worth checking out. Its imagery, performances and plot won't leave you for a while and it will keep you engaged all the way through its long running time.

What everyman fears, loosing his kids to an abductor. Who is it? Where are they? Are they ok? You will run the gamut of emotions from shock, to fear, to revenge, to sympathy and back to vengeance. This movie will test you with how you would act if you thought you knew who the abductor was and that they potentially could escape justice and your child may die, if you don't take matters into your own hands.
Caused some inward reflection of how far I may go to protect those I love.

But I just couldn't. I couldn't even finish it. Part of that is it was too long. Way too long. Or I just thought it was because I couldn't get into it. I love Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal and their performances were great given the material. I just didn't like the movie. I think the title describes the state of each character in the film. And Paul Dano.... He is so perfect as a creepy dude (this movie and Taking Lives) and a really nasty person (12 Years A Slave). He just skeeves me out when he's in character.

I really was intrigued by this movie. It was worth the price.  I don,t go to movie theatres, as the price is exorbitant and inconvenient to me.  This movie holds your attention and keeps you guessing 'til the end and then some!
Ughhh the ending got me though. Didn't see it coming. Every good acting! Hugh was awesome like always! Must see

I liked "Prisoners" a lot - thought it lived up to expectations more than most current dramas.

There was an awful lot of foreshadowing and it is pretty drawn out so I can understand some of the negative reviews.  you have to understand that the audience sees the whole situation unfolding while the detective and father only see half of the facts.

There were a few style cliches that were overtly noticeable to me - the biggest being the weather constantly setting the tone of the scene - really, constantly.  The mother being a worthless emotional wreck was a bit overdone.  The whistle being so important throughout was definitely strained.

Overall, a very good movie.  Its depressing, so its a "one viewing and done viewing" kind of thing I'd recommend a rental over a purchase.

Ending was annoying. Amazon video cc sucks unless you have 20-15 vision; why it changed recently makes no sense. Hugh's role a bit overdone.

The movie trailers were catchy and the review raved about the movie.  However, I just don't get what the rave is all about.  The movie was very interesting (even though a few things just did not make sense), but by the time the movie was over, there were many issues that were left unanswered, leaving many gaps in the story.  All in all, the movie was entertaining but disappointing at the end (I'm glad I didn't spend money to see this at the theater).

This picture hold your face in the limits of human emotional endurance, as well as a lot of human weakness. That said, there is not one minute Prisoners isn't a very good movie. Be prepared to ask yourself important questions, because all of us have our limits.
This one had me fooled, I wasn't sure how it was going to end. It's a pretty strange movie, but it was definitely very intense, and I liked both Jake and Hugh in this one.

No Spoilers until marked.

This movie represents some of the best acting, and tightest plot spinning I have ever seen on screen! Prepare yourself for a very emotional, suspenseful, anxiety ridden maze-like trip through a parent's worst nightmare- this movie hits home hard for those of us with children but it's breathtaking raw emotion, keep-you-guessing type plot, and fantastic acting makes it well worth the heartache.

The acting is fantastic all around but Jake Gyllenhaal, Hugh Jackman, and Paul Dano steal the show! By the end of the movie, I was left especially hungry to learn more about Gyllenhaal's "Detective Loki." The details of his character are incredibly interesting and fitting for his role. Jackman was intense... and I do mean INTENSE. His visceral desperation and anger are felt more than just seen. And Dano brings something to the screen that I have never before seen. We are told he is a mentally disadvantaged man with an intellect no greater than a ten year old and the way this plays out on screen is just brilliant. I'll leave it at that for this non-spoiler part of the review. The rest of the cast does very well also, particularly Terrence Howard and Viola Davis as Franklin and Nancy Birch though the movie does not center around their characters quite as much.

The cinematography was brilliant. There were some scenes that could easily have been movie posters, I won't spoil them for you. Overall the movie was beautifully shot.

As far as music and sound go, I have to say I don't remember any of the music from the film. This is not necessarily a bad thing as I would prefer it not be memorable in a bad way so as to distract from what is being portrayed but it also means that it wasn't amazing. The sound, however, is a different story. There were moments of complete silence in the movie where the silence itself was a sound effect. There were intense moments that were accented by incredibly clear and poignant sound that fit the scene.

Plot, oh boy was there plot! A great, edge of the seat, thrilling plot that just smacked me in the face every couple of minutes! The movie goes on for about 2.5 hours and the whole time I was glued to the screen. What an incredible story!

********WARNING: HUGE SPOILERS BELOW, don't read any further unless you have seen the movie or for some reason just want to destroy the experience of watching this film for yourself.
*******************************************************************************************************************

Ok, just so we are all on the same page, I am going to go through the plot and piece things together since there seems to be a bit of confusion on Who Bobby Taylor was, how joy escaped, and what the Leo's were actually doing to children.

We start off being introduced to Keller Dover and his son , Ralph. Keller recites the Lord's Prayer and his son lines up a shot for a deer. This scene is blatantly metaphorical for "doing what is necessary" in Keller's perspective. It also shows how Ralph is becoming a man. This plays well against Alex Jones because it shows you what Alex never had and why he isn't a "man" but rather still a 10 year old boy. (Obviously abuse and drugs/snake venom had something to do with it too). This is how Keller works, he doesn't enjoy killing the deer but it is necessary to him and the ends justify the means. The prayer shows us that he doesn't "shoot the deer" for his own enjoyment, it is a means by which he can get what he needs for his family. This foreshadows the exact sentiment felt when he tortures Alex.

We can now skip ahead to the children disappearing. We meet Detective Loki. He has tattoos but he hides them constantly. He clasps his hands to hide his knuckle tattoos and he buttons his shirt to the top button to hide his neck tattoos. He wears a masonic ring, His tattoos and his opening lines indicate that he has an interest in Zodiac signs and astrology- all information we are given throughout the film indicates that he had a rough past and was possibly a criminal turned cop. Loki is a prisoner of his past.

Keller becomes a prisoner to his desperation, doing things he would never have done under normal circumstances, likewise his wife becomes a prisoner to her medication as a way of dealing with the tragedy of losing her daughter. Ralph becomes a prisoner of the house, his father the jailor. He is told to watch over his mother and stay home. Alex becomes Keller's prisoner in a very literal sense.  The children are obviously prisoners- I could go on. Everyone in the movie is a prisoner to something by this point.

The RV is gone over CSI-Miami style and nothing is found- this is because Alex merely let the kids in, let them play and sing while he drove them to his "aunt's" house. This is what he meant when he said "They didn't cry until I left them." It also explains Ms. Leo's later comment that he only played with the children. Loki continues tracking down leads by visiting local sex offenders and happens upon a body in the creepy as f*** basement/crawl-space/nightmare-dungeon under the Priest's house. This body is wearing a necklace with a  circular maze etched on it, hmmmmm. It is also explained that the man has kidnapped and killed at least 16 children. This man is Ms. Leo's husband that she said disappeared after a fight. He is also the "invisible man" that the book in Bobby Taylor's house is about.

Speaking of Bobby Taylor, aka "The Snake Guy," he was a former abductee, taken by the Leo's when he was  just a boy. He escaped somehow, it isn't ever explained, but he is now damaged and seeks to recreate the efforts of his captors to try and understand their motives. He is obsessed with it, going as far as stealing abducted children's clothes, spattering them with pigs blood and claiming to have killed them. He buries child-manikins in his yard after bashing in their heads. He is a mixture of a victim with Stockholm syndrome, a child, and a copycat killer. He too, is a prisoner to his past, he even goes so far as to wear the same jacket as Ms. Leo does (more on that later).

So the Leo's have had a process that is now continued only by Ms. Leo since Mr. Leo is dead. By the end of the movie, we should be able to conclude that The Leo's had a son who died of cancer. They were religious prior to this and afterward, unable to reconcile the tragedy with their religion, they reject their religion and begin to "wage war on god" by abducting other people's children, creating "demons" aka the broken, parents of the abducted children. They do this alone at first and later by having Alex find and pick up children. The children are then delivered to the Leo's house where they are given Kool-Aid laced with ketamine and LCD and told that they can leave when they have solved a book fool of mazes. The catch is, the last maze, the same one that Mr. Leo wore around his neck, is unsolvable. Eventually the children are injected with snake venom and buried. This is exactly what happened to Joy and Anna but Joy was able to get away before she was injected. (Some might argue that there is a different order to it but this is the gist. All these things happen, it may be done in a different order depending on the kid)

How did Joy get away? The movie tells you but it is a bit difficult to piece it together. We see Joy's flash backs when she is in the hospital room and it shows a person wearing a jacket carrying Anna in the right arm and reaching for Joy (who is running away) with her left. It also shows two bottles of the laced Kool-Aid, one full and one half empty. We can deduce that it was Ms. Leo in the Jacket, and that Joy did not drink her Kool-Aid. This fits with what Ms. Leo said about having to move the girls inside after Detective Loki was snooping around the car outside. Thus when Ms. Leo was moving them inside, Joy ran away and was picked up by a passing motorist.

All this is pieced together when Keller visits Joy in the hospital and she says "You were there. She put tape on our mouths!" Keller thinks back and realizes the only place he has gone where there was a female suspect was the Leo's home. Joy must have heard his voice through the thin walls. He gains entry by half-heartedly pretending to offer assistance fixing up the house and ignores the obviously hidden weapon in her hand. This is the only part of the plot that made me cringe. We all knew she had a gun, and Keller should have too.

So he gets drugged, shot,  and thrown in the pit- Loki finds Alex in Keller's old apartment building, in pretty bad shape assumingly. He is tasked with telling Ms. Leo they found Alex. Detective Loki lets himself in, finds Ms. Leo injecting Anna with venom and a firefight ensues, in which Loki gets grazed on the head and Ms. Leo gets gunned down. The scene where Loki drives Anna to the hospital was amazing. The lighting, the blurry eyes, the rain, the anxiety... MAN! PERFECT!

The end of the movie wraps up pretty neatly. Loki hears Keller blowing the whistle and we know that he finds Keller, and we know that Keller goes to Jail (based on previous comments made by Loki in the hospital).

This movie used the maze as a theme constantly. Think about how you would solve a maze on a piece of paper, following one trail until it dead ends and having to backtrack and pick a different branch, sometimes overlooking the right path until it is the only one left. That is how the plot played out, that is how each prisoner felt inside their prison. Beautiful.

This one makes the Top 5 List for 2013, You have Never seen Jackman in a role like this, don't Ever mess with one of his Children. This proves Hugh is up for Any role. Filled with riveting emotions and lots of nail biting suspense.

I was coming back by bus from a long weekend trip and they put this movie on. Both my friend and I were tired and had been dozing on and off. And then we started watching this. Sleep= gone. This was riveting from the very beginning and you just knew something awful was about to happen. Even after it happened you kept dreading the next scene and then the next. We reached our bus stop 30 minutes before the movie ended, (first time I ever wanted a bus to be delayed!). But as soon as we got home we got on amazon to watch the rest. This was one of the most unpredictable, brilliantly acted movies I've seen in a while and I highly recommend it.
This was definitely was a nail biter.  The actors were excellent and the movie script very well done.  Keeps you in suspense all through the picture. A must see if you want suspense!
Very well put together! This is a movie that kept me on the edge of my seat and had an ending I would have never imagined!
keeps you on the edge of your seat. a lot of twists! different plot from your normal action suspense dramas.
Good movie.  Topic addressed in a different manner.  Lack of character development is the only thing that stops this movie from being a classic.
I love Hugh Jackman and this was one of his best movies to date.  He knew, we knew in time, but the end results were a surprise.

You will not watch this film twice, and probably hate yourself for watching it once.  Not because of the theme (abducted children), but because this is not a "thriller", it is a boring drama.

But if you must, the only reason you will watch it all the way to the ending is because you are guessing which one of the major stars "did it"?  And their motive.

If the purpose of the film was to ask the moral question: Is torture justified when time is running out and you are searching for your missing daughter?  That question has already been asked in the superior thriller "Taken", and the answer is YES.

Sorry this is not "Taken" and two hours later you will turn to your sweetie and say "WTF!  That's it?"  This is a disappointing story that does not deliver a clever or unique ending.  You were duped by the 5 star reviews.

The only actor who partially survives this debacle is Maria Bello -- because her character takes tranquilizers and heads to bed, not to be seen for most of the movie, therefore she has no character development, no great dialog, and does not contribute in any way to story development -- and certainly not the climax of the film.

And what's with Jake Gyllenhaal's raccoon eye make-up and nervous eyeball twitching?  Was that suppose to add depth to his character and possibly suspicion (who did it)?

Read the bad review before wasting 2 hours on this routine melodrama.  I was fooled by a friend who highly recommended the movie.  Knowing her movie preferences, I should have known better.
video stopped 10-15 minutes before the end.  some kind of problem with SILVERLIGHT???? which has been a problem in the past.  This truly sucks.  No way to fix --
This is a great movie with great actors performing well.  I was completely surprised by how much I enjoyed the movie.  If you like crime TV and crime based movies, then you'll dig this movie.

"I haven't seen many films like it, it is well worth the price of admission..."

Read the full review here:
[...]

Good story?  Check.  Great performances?  Check.  Well-directed?  Check.

But I can't recommend it because it's just so dang disturbing that I don't want to be responsible for you seeing it.  I happened to watch Seven Psychopaths the previous week, and seeing this so shortly after gives me a good way to define "graphic" violence versus "strong" violence.  Seven Psychopaths was graphic in that you see lots of blood and gore, while Prisoners doesn't (in fact, it will often cut away from violent scenes, leaving it up to your imagination).  But Prisoners was much more unsettling because of the way it was presented.  Frankly, the movie is dang creepy on many levels.

But it's a great movie when evaluated on its own merits.  It delivers a complete story without any cop-outs and the viewer can look back on the movie after it ends and see the clues left along the way.  In that sense, it's an outstanding film.  But it will probably be too disturbing for many viewers.
This movie is awesome. It is nearly 2 1/2 hours but it is so involving it seems like minutes. The ending was a complete surprise. I would definitely recommend this!
Overall good and intriguing movie, just some unnecessary excessive foul language. The acting was superb and I would watch it again

There are no "spoilers" here.  The trailer left me with the impression that this was just a movie about a crazed father who kidnapped a man he thought kidnapped his daughter and tortured him to get answers.  It is that but it is so much more. A thriller and real mystery movie with more twists and  turns than Lombard Street in San Francisco.  The end of this movie will leave you speechless.  This is the best movie I've seen in a year or more.

Hugh Jackman gives a face to vigilante justice with all it's righteous ugliness.  I actually felt sorry for the would be perp.  This story has twist after twist and quality acting that does a good job at making one stop and think about what we would turn into if it was one of our children.  I don't want to let too much out of the bag to spoil the movie so I will end here.  Anyone who finds it boring did not watch it all.

The trailers suggested a muddled family crisis drama, but this turned out to be a direct, though nuanced, detective story. Strong performances by all involved support an interesting narrative style that fully justified the longer running time. Sometimes you wonder why so many big names want to be in a movie, but in this case it was quite clear. Well worth the rental.
Great Movie & a great cast. Makes you think..."What would I do in this situation". Ending makes you want for more!
I think this was a great movie. It kept us in suspense until the end. You really feel for the dad in this situation, but he's not the only person who's been hurt.
why is it necessary to use the "F" word? It was an excellent movie, but the foul language really put me off.
Enjoyed the depth of character development. Plot evolved throughout film with no flat spots. Even the weather fits perfectly with this dark drama.
Amazingly written and acted. We loved it!  Very disturbing and thought provoking! The movie keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time.
It has a good star line-up and definitely a good twist and suprise ending.  I wish the ending would have given more.

I wasn't sure I wanted to see this movie when it was in the theater, because it was about a topic that could really happen.  I friend saw it and sad it was good.  This movie was terrific and keeps you on the edge of you seat.  It is nice not to be able to figure out the ending.

this movie has great suspense but moves a bit slow. I did enjoy it even though its a big long also.

Had to give this one an "Okay" rating.  Not exactly as good as I expected with the great cast... quite honestly it was just a little predictable.  It's an alright movie if you're bored & nothing else looks good.  This one will probably hit Netflix in no time at all.
The ending should have played out to show whether or not the detective located little Anne's father.  The movie was good, but did not like the ending.
It was one of those movies where you thought you knew where it was going right up toward the very end.  All the actors did a fantastic job!  HELD MY ATTENTION THROUGHOUT!
Holy Moly this was a good movie.  Very intense and definitely a nail bitter.  A must see, but take your blood pressure medicine before you start the movie, hahaha.

I cannot fathom all the great reviews for this movie.  It is way too long, Gyllenhall is the lone cop assigned to a double kidnapping case and stumbles through it like Eddie Munster on Quaaludes (there must be huge back story here, but thank God they didn't include it), so many, many plot holes it's ridiculous ... it makes no logical sense at all. What could have been a good movie turned into a Hollywood embellishment of an interesting story.  Acting was good, editing was horrible, way to many improbable scenes - especially the car rush to the hospital. Why does Hollywood seem to think everyone is interested in a car chase melodrama.  This was as bad as the chasing scene in 'Argo'.  There are better movies out there.
this movie keeps you on edge till the VERY END. definatly a suspense movie! I would recommend it to anyone.
I thought it was very intense and the ending kept you guessing.  What I didn't like was the obscenities  used by the actors.  Not necessary.
One of the best movies ever seen over the past couple of years .Jake Gylenhal is amazing as the lead detective
Was a lot better than i thought it would be,got some good twist in the movie,worth the time to watch
It kept me watching thru out the entire film. Great movie to watch. It will keep you on your toes.

Loved it. Keeps you on the edge of you seat. The story that is. I know Maria Bello and Terrance Howard can act better, but this is not one of their better movies. Unfortunately, it had a lousy ending. Still worth seeing though.

I love Hugh Jackman and do not understand why he and Jake Gyllenhaal were not Oscar-nominated for their performances.
I just finished watching this movie on Netflix and am still trying to process it.  It is so much more than the kidnapping of 2
little girls on Thanksgiving.  All of the performances were extraordinary and it was hard to watch at times but I could not
stop watching.  It is intense, disturbing, dark and suspenseful.  Did Loki respond to the whistle or not?  I will always wonder.
