I am very critical of movies and they have to be really good to keep my attention. This one was exactly that, great actors, wonderful plot and suspenseful as they come. I want to watch this again and would actually buy this because it was so good.
Tense thriller without any holes.  Thoroughly entertaining nail biter with great acting.  Hugh Jackman carried the movie with a strong performance!
Way too long.  Also boring.  I could not stay awake. The acting was okay, but the story plodded along at a slow pace.  I would not recommend.
Very interesting and a lot of action!  Suspenceful and good acting!  Out come is not always what you expect it to be.
we watched this with our teenage boys - we all enjoyed very much.  we really enjoyed because it was not predictable.

Practically nothing about Hugh Jackman's character is believable. Cliches stacked on cliche mixed with  reactions that no human would ever have, that can only live on paper, in a script. Although I must say that the photography indeed is very nice, props are  sometimes a little too over-explaining. For example, is it really necessary to show 10 or so semi emptied empty liquor bottles in someones home to establish that the guy living there is a drunk? Yes, one bottle was tilted also.

The movie moves slooow. Save your money and time.

SEE THIS MOVIE!  Great suspense and superb acting.  The scariest movie for  grown ups since Psycho.
You won't be disappointed.
the video stopped streaming at climax of the movie! this was a hard hitting movie so it would have been nice to see the ending.
Very intense movie. Keeps you on pins and needles through out the entire movie.  A true thriller, with good story line.

Was kept on the edge of my seat the entire duration of the film.  I was moved to the depths of my being throughout.  Hugh Jackman's intensity was stunning.  This film did an amazing job capturing the power of love and the extremes it will go to to protect the object loved.  Highly recommend.
Hugh Jackman & Jake Gyllenhall were great in these roles. The rage of a father & frustration of a detective filled every scene. A definite must watch if you enjoy thrillers.
I enjoyed the movie! The acting was very good and they had a good cast. The plot was ok but not great! All in all we were happy that we rented it on Amazon!
I loved the movie , it makes your mind wonder with a twist , if you haven't seen it what are you waiting on !!

This could have been a good movie if the editors of the film would have watched it first. The scenes would go from rain to snow on the ground back to rain  yet this represented a 3 hour window in the movie. They made a point of calling out certain things in a scene (like the phone in the garbage disposal) and then never came back to it. Hugh Jackman does a good job and is believe able as a grief stricken father who would do anything to find his daughter. Jake Gyllenhaal is less convincing as the detective investigating.

This was one of the most unrealistic and boring movies that I've seen. I could not get past the first 30 minutes. After seeing the star studded cast of academy award nominees, my expectation level was high. Unfortunately, the script and pace of the movie was not worthy of the talents of this extraordinary cast. Hopefully, the cast will have an opportunity to work together again in the future on something that meets their level of talent.

I thought the movie itself was just okay, but thought the acting was spot on.  Not the prettiest parts for Hugh and Jake, but they play the seedy side very well.  The storyline itself intriguing, but the last half hour could have been screened better.  Where was his truck?

The movie starts out with great promise.  Prisoners has some entertainment value with its cast of stars.  It's not their fault that they didn't write an implausible script.  Jake Gylenhal (sp) always delivers in his films.  But this movie played out like a typical horror movie in which you are yelling at the characters to grow a brain.  The movie plays out almost 40 mins. too long.  It's like the director started the project, was insecure, and tried to explain everything at the end to wrap it up nicely.  Overall, the suspense and darkness keeps a nice mood throughout the movie.  But the inexplicable moves of the characters makes them just dumb and with no redeeming qualities.  If you just want a movie to escape than Prisoners is the movie for you.  But if you're like me that sets the bar with the Coen bros., than this movie will insult your intelligence.  Happy movie watching over the holidays!

-fbclaw
Yes, it was a maze, treat children with kindness so they won't grow up to be rigid religious finantics. fold..

Prisoners subverts the stereotyped male predator and leaves the viewer with a new culprit of white evil
More realistic than the media would have you believe... WATCH it and SEE!
This movie is very suspense filled and keeps you watching until the very end.  Keeps you right on the edge of your seat.

Good action throughout and lots of drama to keep you interested.  Touches on your own personal thoughts of how you would react if it was your kid.  Top of the line movie here...  Out of the park hit Hugh!!!!!!
watched it twice and couldn't figure it out at all I was very very disappointed and wished I hadn't rented it
I wasn't 100% sure about this one but it turned out to be a great movie. Worth a couple of hours of your night.
Really enjoyed this movie.  Very suspenseful throughout the movie.  Have been waiting for a good movie like this to come out for a long time.  Highly recommend watching it.
Thrilling suspense without unnecessary effects - just great acting, set and direction. Highly recommended. It plays into what could really happen.
Suspenseful! Was at edge of my seat....was frustrated at times at main character taking matters into his own hand but was good movie

This was the most intense movie that I have seen to date.  Every part of the movie held my attention,  the acting from both Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal was riveting.  I was scared, I cried, anxious, etc.,  If you want to get lost and captivated by a movie, THIS IS IT!!!!!!!
This was a Great movie...couldn't stop thinking about it for a few days. Haven't seen a movie like that in a while.
Some things in the movie were left hanging without an explanation. A little bit confusing. movie was way too long.
Kinda gives you that dark creepy feeling like I got from watching Silence of the Lambs.  Hugh Jackman is great!
Bit long but solid performance. Jake G is a standout and Jackman is always a fav.  Great cast of players good tempo for the majority
A white-knuckled journey through a who-done-it with numerous twists and turns. A little gruesome/violent, but overall entertaining and well acted.

A bit predictable but the morality story is worth watching.
We all must ask ourselves when, and if ever, is violence needed. Is there any situation that becoming a monster is worth it?
Movie was fantastic, kept me on the edge of seat, great acting, would highly recommend! Do not hesitate to watch!
it was an amazing gripping movie. i rarely get surprised during movies, i usually am one step ahead. Can be gut-wrenching at times.
Very well made movie! Great acting from Hugh Jackman. Excellent plot. Duration of the movie is slightly longer than usual, but nevertheless very engaging.

I have mixed feelings for this movie, on the one hand i enjoyed it because it leaves you wondering who? why? and you stay focused in to find out! i enjoy the wonder of ????
then on the other hand, after its all over (like 3 hours worth) im still left with WHY????  im still thinking WHY?  i now know WHO?  but thats about it-  and it truly bugs the sh-- out of me.  if your watching it just because xmen dude is in it then you may not care for details and just want a thrill ride- but that don't work for me- i want answers to ALL questions!
and as far as xmen dudes role.  Get used to alot of him just yelling at someone for most of the movie (that got annoying after 5 mins of it)  oh hell- just watch it and decide for yourself-  im tired of it=

I can't believe I never heard about this Movie. Its in the same class as "Seven". It is a drama mystery that gives you enough clues as to keep you guessing, and probably figuring out some things, but not enough to spoil the ending. I leaned forward in my seat many times in anticipation while watching. Great movie!

This was quite good and had a very European feel to it throughout. A really different role for Hugh Jackman but he did a fine job of portraying a father coming unhinged. Had some nice surprises throughout and the look of the film was really good. All washed out colors that matched the material very well.

I should make it clear though... IF you can handle it. Most of my friends with children just simply couldn't take this movie which is painful to watch at times, especially for parents. If you want to see Huge Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal at their absolute BEST. See this movie.
Great acting and better directing. Serious, creepy thriller that keeps you guessing throughout the entire film. This is a must watch.
Just how far are you willing to go before you become a vigilante when you find Justice lacking? I guess it's difficult to hold back in situations like this one..

Unlike much of the mental pablum that is served up to moviegoers nowadays, this is a very entertaining movie with excellent performances, and an engrossing story that suspenseful and surprising. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhall? are terrific as is the entire cast. If you are serious about movies of substance, don't miss this one.
Suspenseful kept me on the edge of my seat.  Hugh Jackman did an amazing job with this movie. Loved it
Movie was good. Didn't see the ending coming.  I thought the acting was very good as well.  It could have been a little shorter.
Excellent. Suspense. .mystery. .watch it.. hugh jackman and gyllenhall are at their best. One of the better thrillers I've seen.
It was a nice thriller. There were some bad plot points missed and i did not like the ending but overall a good watch.
Brilliant cast. Great movie. The suspense kept building through out and the twists and turns were well done. Enjoyed the ending.
One of the best films of 2013, Prisoners is a bleakly beautiful and gripping thriller/drama that makes for disturbing, engrossing and fascinating viewing. I highly recommend this movie.

I really enjoyed watching this movie. The twists and turns left me guessing what was next. Usually, I am the one who ruins a movie about 1/4 of the way through it because I blurt out who did it... "The Butler did it!!" and then everyone else watching the movie gets upset when I am right, but with this one, it was a thrill all the way to the closing credits.
If you like mystery thrillers, this movie will have you focused on the screen.

My advice is don't watch the trailer before watching.  That is what we did, we got it based just on who was in it and the rating and it made the movie even better to watch because we had no idea what was going to happen.  It kept us on our toes the whole time.
This was a really good movie, very well done.  It kept our attention to the very end.  Fantastic acting all the way around, but Jake Gyllenhaal was the stand out for us...he was so good in his role, down to mannerisms and slight movements.  And nothing gratuitous or lazy, just stuck to the story and told it well.

The lovely bones was a far better film.
It's sad that there are creeps in this world. But the storyline was pretty unbelievable in this film.

All the characters were so real, like it could happen to you. Their portrayals made you feel their, pain, heartache and struggle. I recommend highly if you can handle realism and drama. They is no suger coating a parents ache and crazyiness that we as parents feel in a time of dispair. Good movie, hope they get oscar nom.
Best suspense movie since Hitchcock's Psycho....this movie is a must...more twist and turns than you can imagine...could not put this movie together
Don't miss this one.  It will keep your attention from beginning to end.  I thought it would be good...it was much better.

From start to finish this movie will keep you engaged as to what happened, who done it, and what will happen. Great acting, direction, and story line. Very rarely is a movie that is actually realistic and remains entertaining. The story-line and characters kept you wanting to know more and while it was over 2 hours long, there was never a dull moment. It did a great job at making you think a situation was going to be a minor part of the story, but then it completely turns into an important element/event in the story. The ending will definitely be a "good" surprise/twist, but is very realistic. My fiance and I went back and rewatched some scenes after the movie that ended up being important details to the case.

Although, I can't say enough good things about this movie, but I will say this; While it's not very gruesome or at all sexual, It's not something I'd recommend for pre-teen children or people who find child abduction stories particularly distiburbing. The movie will surpise you at how likely something like this could happen (has happened), so don't watch it if you can't appreciate it for what it is. Again, I can't say enough good things about this movie, so I highly recommend giving it a chance.

A decent movie but a bit far fetched.  I found myself listing all the gross improbabilities when it ended.  The 'hero' if you can call him that is just a misguided vigilante who causes great harm to an innocent.
I didn't know what to expect with this movie.  It's a great story, that makes you think about what you would do if put in the situation.  Great performances across the board.
Great who dunnit.  Enjoyed watching this movie!  Kept me wondering throughout and liked the ending especially.  Worth watching and renting!

I thoroughly enjoyed the performances by all the cast in this thriller. Very well done and entirely creepy. I have young children and found this psychologically scary rather then the classic blood and guts. Be sure to watch this when the kids are out of the room...no need to expose them to this level of stranger danger. Hugh Jackman killed it on this one.
Very good acting. Kept your interest right until the end. Would not recommend for younger people or those who cannot stand violence.
Great film. The last hour will keep you on the edge of your seat. Hugh jackman is remarkable. Great twist.
Great movie with lots of twists and turns. If you watch/listen carefully you can come up with some of the answers. Was fun to guess with the clues they gave. Very we'll put together and great acting.

It was great to see Hugh Jackman embrace a part that didn't require he growl or mince about. He made a conservative Christian survivalist a sympathetic character - not the easiest job in this culture.
Jake Gyllenhaal is so interesting. The older he gets the better he gets. There was clearly a huge back story to the cop he played and it was used skillfully to add to the present movie not distract from it. From the tattoos to the facial ticks, this mat be his best acting job ever.
I love it when actors get their teeth in and really master a character to the point that we BELIEVE everything that is happening on screen. Nice work. SO imagine my fear when I saw that Maria bello was in this film. I was scared that I was going to have to watch her version of bullish post feminism that she brings to nearly every role she plays. Not a subtle actress at all.
BOY, WAS I WRONG!!!
She played the broken betrayed wife with such sympathy that I nearly cried when she did and I ached for her loss and confusion at the loss of her daughter. Really nice work!
Finally, without giving anything away, Kudos to the director or writer or who ever thought up the ending: Grand and electrifying subtlety, simply brilliant.

I advise you to SEE THIS FILM.

I rented this movie because of the actors that star in it and the trailer really caught my eye.  Hugh Jackman is one of a kind and even though the movie is over 2 hours, it does a very, very good job of telling the entire story.  At first it seems like you are going to walk your way through this movie, especially if you have seen other movies with the same subject matter, but that is not the case.

Not knowing how the movie is going to end is a hard element to get into a movie these days when everything has been done.  This one really makes you feel for the main characters as they are ALL put into very tough situations throughout.

Excellent and even though it is quite long compared to other movies these days, it does the job.  Enjoy!
Great acting by all!  This movie has surprises at every turn.  If you like thrillers, this is the best we've seen in years!
This was a very interesting movie. It kept you pretty well in suspense until the end. It also didn't drag on over the smal details like some movies do. Very entertaining.

This movie was very good. There were alot of twists, turns, subtle hints and suspense, to keep you glued to the television.
Definetely worth watching. I really didn't care for the ending.

I love watching thrillers. I would have to say I'm pretty good at figuring out the mystery before the ending. This movie was the exception. Great acting all away around. I absolutely loved the ending with the whistle. Nice touch!!!

Gyllenhaal is outstanding and Jackmann is solid.

The movie is engaging, suspenseful, and has an original perspective on the kidnapping genre.  I imagine this movie is significantly more compelling to folks with kids or who have some that are very close to them.

It is complex enough to keep you from figuring it out until it unfolds on the screen but, doesn't take too many leaps to make it unbelievable.

Finally, the movie is an interesting guide through the topic of whether torture is ever justified.  Purchase/rent with confidence and get ready for a really solid thriller.
Being a father this movie struck my core.  Lots of Twists and turns kept me on edge and praying for a merciful outcome to the horror.

A very smart spin on a common theme; and in no way boring. Mystery within mystery all the way through.
Not a thriller to pass on. Great movie.

Prisoners is yet another installment in the crime/abduction movie genre starring Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal.  Prisoners is not really my type of movie.  Im not generally into crime dramas whether it be crime/abduction movies or the few dozen crime dramas on television like CSI, Criminal Minds, NCIS, Law and Order, etc.  I would not have seen this film had it not have starred Hugh Jackman or Jake Gyllenhaal.

I am a big fan of Hugh Jackman.  He is the perfect Wolverine.  No one could have played Wolverine better.  I have also seen many of his other films as well like the Fountain, Les Miserable, Real Steel, etc.  While some of his movies I do not care for like the Fountain, I still loved his performance in them.  He is a very talented actor and deserves an Oscar at this point.  Hopefully he gets one for his performance in this film.  I also like Gyllenhaal as an actor.  I thought he was good in the Day After Tomorrow and I thought he was great in Zodiac.  Without these two this movie would not have been as good.  They were both amazing in this film.

I knew the film would at least be decent because those two actors were in it and the film is getting pretty good reviews so far on Rotten Tomatoes.  I saw the film and I liked it.  I will say that out of all the crime drama films that I have seen I would that this is one of the better ones.  It is well acted by everyone in the cast, not just by Jackman and Gyllenhaal.  The story was also good and fairly well executed.  I will also admit that this film does something a little bit different than most crime dramas that I have seen.

The story is fairly simple.  It is very much like it was advertised in the trailers.  You have two families.  One family consists of a man named Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), his wife Gracie Dover (Maria Bello), his son Ralph, and his daughter Anna.  The other family consists of a man named Franklin (Terrence Howard), his wife Nancy (Viola Davis), his eldest daughter Eliza, and the youngest daughter Joy.  The two children, Anna and Joy, end up being abducted by an unknown individual.  An investigator named Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) to investigate the case.  They have the primary suspect named Alex in custody.  However, they cannot find anything on him and release him.  Dover obsessed with getting his daughter back and takes the law into his own hands.

The movie is very good, but it is not a movie that can be watched casually.  It is very depressing and does not end the best.  The characters do some pretty messed up things that make you like them less, but you do see where they are coming from.  This movie is very much like films like the Departed, Seven, Gone Baby Gone, Mystic River, etc.  They are well-done films, but they leave you depressed and are not films you can really re-watch.  I do like prisoners more than most of those films though.

This film at least did not have an entirely depressing ending.  It is not really a happy ending, but more bittersweet.  To be honest that is really the only way this movie could have ended though.  I usually prefer triumphant endings, but this one could not really end happily.  From what occurs in the movie and certain actions the main character takes, if the film ended happily it would have felt like a cop out.

Overall, Prisoners is a well-done crime drama.  I will say that this, Zodiac, and The Dark Knight (yes I count it as a crime drama) are my favorite films in this particular genre.  It is well-acted well plotted and well executed.  If you like crime dramas then give this a look.

I'm half way through this movie and I don't think I can make it all the way through. A very slow and boring examination of how low humans can sink when tragedy hits their lives.

I managed to make it through this movie but I cannot recommend it. My time and money was wasted.
The best movie I've seen in years.  Amazingly acted, written, and directed.  I would give 10 stars if i could.

Excellent movie. Definitely not for the light-hearted individuals that like upbeat movies, but if you can grasp a difficult, heavier concept of being willing to do anything to find your child, you'll really enjoy this film.

I  just  finished  this  movie,  &  although  it  is  quite  long...or  at  least  it  seems  like  it  takes  forever  to  end,  it  was  very  good. Good  acting  on  everyones  part. A  bit  creepier  than  I  like  in  some  respects.  Not  slasher-style,  but  snakes.  I  hate  snakes.  Everything  starts  to  tie  in  together  and  starts  to  make  sense  about  20  minutes  or  so  from  the  end.  But  it  kept  me  riveted.

Great movie with several plot twists. I would call it tense more than suspenseful, but it keeps you wondering and guessing throughout. Some violent scenes involving torture of a suspected bad guy (it gives that away in the preview so I'm not spoiling anything) that may be disturbing to some, but might make you wonder if you would do the same given the circumstances. Note that it's 2.5 hrs long, so settle in and get comfy. You'll be surprised by the interesting ending.

Wow !  It has been a long time since I have seen a movie this good !  Superb acting, thrilling, will keep your interest until the very end ! Congratulations to everyone who has been involved in this movie.  Superb !
Terrific movie. Perfect amount of suspense and solid acting. The end was just a bit of a letdown. I would like to have had a little more closure.
This movie kept interested the entire time. I have recommended it to anyone who will listen!! The acting was incredible.

Very well done and riveting. Jake continues to impress me as he grows into each of his roles. I knew years ago he was a young man worth following. I look forward to his future efforts.

Grandpabob1953
Very emotional film that probably is exactly what any parent would feel if a child went missing. The acting was superb all around. Well worth the time.

Jackman and Gyllenhaal should work together often as they generate a plausible degree of friction and suspense that grips the viewer from the beginning and does not let go.  Oscar-worthy work from both, although I doubt they'll actually be nominated, since - as usual - the people who determine who is nominated for stellar performances are too busy jumping on the latest bandwagon to actually compare apples to apples.  Sorry - awards season always annoys me to no end. :)

As Detective Loki, Gyllenhaal is a revelation in that he seems to have deliberately abandoned any suggestion of "just another pretty Hollywood face" and poured himself into the role. Facial expressions, mannerisms, wardrobe, posture - even a most unflattering hairstyle - everything about him is intense and perfectly proportioned to the image of a driven, relentless individual whose dedication to his professional responsibilities approach a level of obsession. In addition, he projects his conflicted reactions to Jackman with a degree of subtlety that serves to underscore the brilliance of the performance. A hero, but a completely original version.

On the other hand, Jackman is a bipolar wonder, succeeding in making us understand the desperation of a father willing to go to any lengths to save his child, while forcing us to cringe away from the savage capacity that might exist within us all.

Spoilers ahead, for those who haven't seen it yet.

Finally, Melissa Leo is gripping - not to mention scary as hell - as the benign, soft-spoken paragon of virtue concealing the black soul of a demon living in the heart of darkness.

One of the best of this or any other year.
Intense and disturbing.  Great performances. You will not be disappointed by this movie.  Really gets you to think about how far you would go to find your child...

2013R: Good flick, but amazing how the ending can so dramatically affect a rating.

I would've given this flick a solid 4 star rating, but the 2-5 minutes they 'saved' on the ending cost half a star IMHO. The acting was very good, and the story (although unnoticably long) was interesting and kept moving.

They did an excellent job of handling a distasteful subject without being over the top or excessively graphic. I really hate this kind of stuff, but it does remind us to check the sex-offender map for our neighborhood.

I don't remember who said this, but eternal vigilance is the price we must pay for our children's safety. Good flick. Enjoy MFJLabs 3.5x

Great cast of characters in the film. Hugh Jackman was great in the movie. It was suspenseful and a great whodunnit. I can usually figure out the villian but this one took me by suprise. I would recommend that it's worth the cost of watching....
It kept you interested because you wanted to know who did it and why but didn't like the way it ended
This movie exceeded our expectations. It had plently of layers and was suspenseful throughout the entire movie. Would watch again!

Director Denis Villeneuve shocked us with his masterful `Incendies' and he does it again with this intensely suspenseful highly polished drama PRISONERS written by Aaron Guzikowski. Though the film is quite long (153 minutes) the tension is sustained making the viewer not so much an observer but a member of this funky little cold town where so much evil happens.

The time is the present (the location shooting was Georgia but any small town across the country could well substitute), it is Thanksgiving and two close families are gathered in their neighborhood for the feast; the Dovers - father Keller (Hugh Jackman, mother Grace (Maria Bello), daughter Anna (Erin Gerasimovich) and son Ralph (Dylan Minnette) and the Birches - father Franklin (Terrence Howard), mother Nancy (Viola Davis), daughters Eliza (Zoe Borde) and Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons). Joy and Anna disappear and panic strikes. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street. Heading the investigation, Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) arrests its driver, Alex Jones (Paul Dano), but a lack of evidence forces his release. As the police pursue multiple leads and pressure mounts, knowing his child's life is at stake the frantic Keller Dover decides he has no choice but to take matters into his own hands. His methods involve capturing and torturing Alex with Franklin's help, but neither is sure of the outcome of their interrogation. Twists and turns occur involving a drunken sicko priest (Len Cariou) and the aunt/mother of Alex (Melissa Leo) - both leading to very surprising endings.

The cast is as first rate as they come. Everyone is strong by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal are brilliant. Viola Davis, Melissa Leo, and Maria Bello involve with their usual excellent acting abilities. But in the end credit must go to director Denis Villeneuve for his superb sculpting of this terrifying film. Highly recommended. Grady Harp, December 13

Better than most of the other crap movies they keep making. Jake Gylenhall was great. Probably his best movies since Donnie Darko. I don't want to give anything away, but this movies will keep you guessing the whole time. Just watch it.

I rented the movie based on the high reviews and the acclaim about the great thriller, plot, etc. I think you have to be 13 to find this in any way unpredictable. There are a 1000 movies out there just like this, and I was fairly bored throughout. Not impressed, not original, and not a necessary movie experience for those looking for an innovative plot or intriguing mystery thriller. The reviews are highly inflated.

Good cast and acting. Jackman chews up the scream. Your guessing to the end who really did it and will be
fooled.

the subject of this says it all. great actors and plot, loved it and was on the edge of my seat, though i'm surprised to see no one else a bit "wtf'd!?" about the ending??? was it supposed to be some "inception-espue" ambiguous type ending where it's left up to the viewer to decide ....well. no spoilers.
I still enjoyed it a great deal, a rarity. check it out.

okay one spoiler alert so read no further if you don't want a clue, but regarding the closing scene, I think the shrill sound of a rescue whistle, no matter how muffled, would still travel at least twenty feet or so.
but Donnie darko(I can't spell his real name) really kicked ass in this, without the cast i'm not sure how well it would've worked. definitely demands second viewing. his interrogation scenes, whether in the station or at the door of a house, are really amazing to see, he's a very talented actor. that guy. who one played Donnie darko.

no one else a bit miffed on that subject?

Best movie that I have seen this year. You are kept on the edge of your seat throughout the entire film. Complex story that requires a second viewing to catch all the plot twists. Major kudos to Jackman and Gyllenhaal. This is an Oscar worthy movie!!

This movie is a movie you will never forget, the reviews are real!  I don't usually do reviews, but I did on this one because it has become my favorite.  I am going to buy it and watch it over and over.  The characters are never boring, but continue to increase your interest.  You have no idea what is coming, The subject matter is very sensative, but This 2 1/2 hour movie kept me glued.  2 couples are having Thanksgiving dinner with each others families when 1 little girl from each of the families go missing.  From there on, the plot develops and its a great thrill ride and well worth the purchase:)
This movie kept u on your toes from the begins to the end.  Bet part 2 will b as good

Don't let the big-name stars fool you: PRISONERS has the trappings of a low-budget, independent character study, the kind that rarely finds its audience via the big screen.  Yet, thanks to word-of-mouth and Hugh Jackman, PRISONERS actually became something of a hit.  Goes to show you that occasionally, Hollywood gets it right.

The film follows the Dover and Birch families, whose young daughters go missing over Thanksgiving.  The police quickly find a suspect, but don't have enough evidence to hold him.  Keller Dover, one of the grieving fathers, decides to take matters into his own hands, while determined police detective Loki follows up all possible leads.  The two stories frequently overlap, as suspects are eliminated and the case spirals ever onward.

Let's get one thing straight: PRISONERS is about half an hour, maybe forty-five minutes too long.  There's a lot of padding here; granted, it's meant to be realistic ("hey, coincidences exist"), but it comes off as fluff meant to make this journey last a little longer.  That being said, the story here is a doozy, a solid script elevated by stellar acting.  As Dover, Hugh Jackman delivers a performance that slowly builds on itself.  His character's actions are never fully justified, but Jackman still gives the role a level of intensity that is both fantastic and off-putting (in a good way).  Paul Dano, as the prime suspect, disappears into his role, as he tends to do; every performance he gives is entirely different and captivating.  Viola Davis, Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, and especially Melissa Leo give fantastic turns.  But it is the film's other lead, Jake Gyllenhaal, who comes off as the true stand-out.  His performance is Oscar-worthy, at times over-the-top, yet on other occasions subtle and nuanced.  In a film filled with good actors doing great work, Gyllenhaal manages to stand out from the rest.

A disclaimer, though: PRISONERS is not easy to watch.  Not because it's about child abduction, though that will upset some.  More so, it's the fact that PRISONERS doesn't shy away from moral complexities.  There are some thoroughly disturbing images (thanks to master cinematographer Roger Deakins) that will upset many viewers.  This isn't a film about black and white justice; it's a film about the grey area, about what people are willing to do for a good cause.  As such, PRISONERS is that rare mainstream film that tackles thoroughly complex issues.  True, by its third act, it becomes more of a conventional thriller...but before that?  It's something truly worth watching, right up until the final shot.

As a parent, this was hard to watch all the way through without pausing... it is an intricate story line that has you questioning everything you know and believe to be true. Hugh gives an awesome portrayal as a father in pain and trying to be his family''s hero, not to be the answer, but the solution. I question Terrance's character for being so helpless, however his portrayal showed the broken man that any father would be... and, if this were a real situation, it is hard to guage how one would respond. Prisoners is every parents nightmare come true. A real gut wrencher here... Watch at your own soul's peril.
Excellent plot, we'll acted and directed. Just a super suspense film. The best film of the year by far. Go see it!
Great movie and acting.  Loved the plot.  Ending was not expected.  Kept us on the edge of our seats the whole movie.  Definitely recommend.
It was suspenseful. Kept me guessing until the very end. Did not expect it to end the way it did.
Great flick!  Acting was top notch. Story was compelling and movie was very well directed.  Barely noticed it was 3 hours long.  Will definitely watch again.

This is my favorite movie of 2013, I went to see it twice at the theater. Superb acting and atmosphere, and edge of your seat story with surprising twists, a movie that demands you pay close attention to details. Highly recommend.
Great acting by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhall.  Jackman's pain as a distraught father is palpable. Hated the ending which  leaves you hanging as to outcome of a main character.
Great movie, best I have seen in a long time. I rate this a must see for action movies. Watch it!

Prisoners, starring Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal (I hope that's how you spell his name) is one of the best crime drama films in a long time. It's tense, extremely well acted, and keeps you guessing and on the edge of your seat until the very end.

The story is simple; Hugh Jackman and Terrence Howard (yep, he's in this too) are neighbors whose families gather for Thanksgiving. Everything is gravy, until both of their young daughters are kidnapped. The story then follows Jackman as he launches a relentless crusade to find his daughter. But, Jake G plays the noble but conflicted detective who is on the case to find the two girls. The detective is trying his best to find them in the most 'by the books' way he can but Hell hath no fury like that of a father whose daughter has been taken away from him. Thus, the film asks its viewers "What would you do and how far would you go to find justice?"

The beauty of this film as opposed to other crime films is that it has a very simple plot. Most crime/mystery stories get so caught up in their complexity and convolution that you lose track of the real story at hand. Prisoners keeps it simple and relies on the complexity o its characters to carry the film. Wolverine...er..Jackman, in particular gives a terrifyingly real performance of a father who will stop at nothing to find his daughter. This is by far his best performance in a long time.

There is nothing like getting immersed into a good crime mystery and this is the best one I have seen in a while.  Incredible acting, dark tone, straightforward plot, satisfying resolution, it doesn't get much better than Prisoners.

I just wasted 15 dollars and what seemed like a week of time waiting for a wonderful movie to appear onscreen. It never happened. I read glowing reviews and watched a couple interviews with Jake and Hugh. They are both talented enough to make this sound thrilling and realistic. To me it was a long drawn out depressing film that should have been edited to help make the story watchable. I guessed the connections rather soon in the story and by the time it was revealed I was yawning and laughing at the same time. And what the heck was wrong with Jake's eyes? He constantly looked as if he had a really bad migraine...I kept thinking that he wondered how he got buried in this mess. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY ON THIS STINKER.
Great movie. Keeps you on the edge of your seat through out the movie. I would  recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys thrillers.
Great gotcha sitting on the edge of your seat movie...You will never see things coming...Done very well...My kind of movie!!!

I saw this when it first came out and the thing is you cannot adequately review it because of the twists and turns in the plot. Friends and I asked each other..."Do you think... ..." for days after! It is called Prisoners, we all know the girls are kidnapped but WHO are the real prisoners in this film? Really makes you think!

I give this movie 2 stars..my wife gives it 1 star. The first half of the movie is very good - the acting is great and storyline gets you involved. I don't want to give anything away but just to say the director gets your emotions going and 2/3 of the way through the movie you realize that they enjoy doing just that...playing with your emotions. We were both extremely disappointed with this movie and if I could I'd like to get my money back.

Before I watched Prisoners, I thought of myself as a cynic -- now, if I am to believe this movie, I must know that I am not a cynic, but a realist. There is not a single redeemable character in this movie. They are all unbelievably evil except for the two child victims, who are, almost assuredly so damaged and damned that they will grow up to become just as despicable as the adult characters in this movie. This was the most depressing film I have ever seen, and I am going to try to remove it from my film library because it was just so impossibly dark, and I am ashamed that I spent the money for it without investigating it first. This movie makes Criminal Minds look like Pollyanna..
This movie was so suspenseful and the cast was fantastic!  I can't believe it didn't do  well in theaters. Highly recommended.

Prisoners is a must-see. It could probably have done with about 30 minutes less movie, but it was incredibly well done. I consider this one of Hugh Jackman's best roles to date- and I can't stand Hugh Jackman. It was an amazing performance. I love Jake Gyllenhall and he was very good in this, but then I think he always is. The story was taut, well-written, and I was blown away by what happened. I'm not easily impressed when it comes to mysteries; I tend to figure them out rather quickly. I thought I had this one pegged, or at least mostly figured out and I was only partly right. I couldn't have gotten the rest of it even if I had another 30 minutes worth of movie. There's not much more to say other than Prisoners deserves to be watched. I don't think you will be disappointed.

This movie was simply amazing.  I was on the edge of my seat the whole time.  You have to put yourself in the parents shoes.  This movie will make you think and hold your loved ones a bit more closely.  Great acting as well in this movie.  The filming was dark but perfect.  Everything about this movie was done correctly.  Buy it asap.  Perfect for a cold winter day.

Prisoners is a compelling drama/thriller about two families that are forced to deal with the loss of their young daughters. When the girls go missing over the course of a seemingly normal afternoon, multiple lives are thrown into chaos in the ensuing struggle not just to find the children but also to deal with the cold reality of a world where things like this usually only happen to other people.

The plot of the movie is deceptively straightforward, but the performances and the underlying message of the film are so thickly layered that the film is a deeply engaging experience, in spite of the harsh, disturbing story it tells. This is probably the best acting I've ever seen from either Jackman or Gyllenhaal, not to mention the rest of the cast, including the remarkably talented Paul Dano as the movie's primary suspect in the kidnapping.

For a movie that has so much going on under the surface, there's very little that can be said about it without marring the amazing depth and complexity that it sets up in so many of the characters. Suffice it to say that, by the film's final moment, the title seems to have half a dozen different interpretations, the movie less about what it takes to get justice or right wrongs than it is about the many ways people can find themselves trapped by their own hearts, minds, or actions. Although the movie doesn't have a lot of action in the traditional sense, there is a whole world of turmoil and energy boiling beneath the paper-thin layers of nearly every character, even when they're just sitting and staring into space.

The best example of a movie that takes silence and stasis and turns into something that is nearly impossible to ignore, PRISONERS is one of the best dramas I've seen in a long time, and not the least because it makes absence and doubt into something so riveting and tumultuous.

The setting was absolutely outstanding. Damp, dark and woodsy in a blue collar town with wretched basements, worn out housing and weird ghastly people! The crawl space in this movie deserves an academy award! The rustic surroundings of the environment were captivating and magnificently filmed. Again, another academy award! Loved the acting. Loved the story. I don't sit through too many 2 1/2 hour movies without doing a jig, joggle and shimmy-dig-shaker quake. But this was one of the few. Oh and Hugh Jackman was tenacious. In the end, I can't say it's up there with Silence of the Lambs but, it isn't that far off either. A scratch or 2 below I suppose.
Good movie, you will not be disappointed.  Well maybe at the end, depends how you think it finishes.  I think it ended well, how about you?

this review is on the blu ray disc of the movie, as follows-
movie - 4.5 / 5
video - 5 / 5
audio - 5 / 5

great movie, very very entertaining all the way.
super video and audio on this blu, watched it about 4 times already and enjoyed it every single time.
highly recommended drama for your collection.
get it !!!!

I hadn't planned on watching this because the previews didn't entice me; but I went upon reading rave reviews as well as positive word of mouth from friends. The story sucked me in at first but then at some point it took a turn and became full of endless plot twists and extremely slow pacing. Finally after about an almost three hour running time it just ends. Really?!?!?!!?! I sat through all of that and THAT'S the ending I got?!?!?! You could see the final twist coming a mile away if you payed close enough attention. I spent majority of the second half checking my watch numerous times. Others may love it but I personally hated it. It gets two stars on the strength of it's top notch performances from it's amazing cast. I'm glad it was a free ticket.

I had high hopes for this movie. Why? Because Jake Gyllenhaal has one sick tattoo stuck to the side of his neck. And homemade hillbilly knuckle tats. I have hillbilly blood in my genes, so this character could have been a member of my family. Or even myself. Detective Loki is no ordinary cop. This dude is a super sleuth. With slicked back trailer trash hair and an oxford shirt that's buttoned up all the way to the top, Loki looks more like a sleazy born-again Bible salesman than effective 5-0. Hugh Jackman is ultra-realistic as the dad who is beside himself when his daughter goes missing. Keller Dover uses father's intuition to track down the S.O.B. he thinks is responsible for his kid's disappearance. Then he lays the smack down on his dirty ass. Paul Dano plays the prime suspect, Alex Jones. Dim-witted, soft-spoken, with dorky glasses, this guy is definitely chester material. Jones is the type of individual who would orbit your child's playground during recess in a windowless cargo van with the words "free candy" spray-painted on the side. Instead, this character stereotype gets a convenient upgrade and drives a beat-up RV. Jones and his prehistoric wheels are the only witness to the freak disappearance of 2 young girls. Times a-ticking away when Dover decides to take matters into his own hands and relapses into a booze-fueled game of cat-and-mouse. You would think this movie's subject matter would be depressing, but it features enough scenery-chewing and action to keep this flick from making your heart sink. The characters are both bizarre and very memorable. The ending was neither overly optimistic nor sappy tearjerker. The 2 hour and 30 minute run time is a perfect length, and moves along at an optimized pace. Give this a shot. It's far more convincing than Gyllenhaal's last copper outing in the sub-par End of Watch.

A very strong psychological thriller about a kidnapping incident. Two little girls in rural Pennsylvania disappear while their families enjoy a Thanksgiving dinner. The story focuses on the case detective, who works in incredibly understaffed and under- equipped conditions, and on the parents.
While the  police makes little progress for several days, one of the fathers takes things in his own hands by kidnapping the first suspect, who had been released from custody for lack of proof.
Hard to tell more without spoilers, so this is all I am telling of the story.
It is one of the best films in this genre that I have watched in some time. I would see its only flaw in the somewhat contrived solution to the mystery. 4.5 stars.
The pressure on the parents and the detective produce  strong suspense, carried by a great cast. One or the other Oscar nomination would be in order. I am thinking mainly of Jackman, who does very well as one of the fathers.

I'd like to warn you this movie will make you feel depressed, and very unsettled even after it ends. So, if you're looking for a lighthearted film that makes you feel happily satisfied, you should stay away.

It suspensefully and skillfully depicts that people are not what they seem to be. Just like in reality, people cannot detect killers by judging their appearances. People were shocked when they found out the killers were the people they thought they knew well.

What makes it unsettling is the tunnel vision of one of the characters that brings tragic consequences.  This strikes a chord with me because I've seen it repeated many times in real life as shown on Dateline NBC shows. Hugh Jackman's acting convincingly increases the unsettling of the picture. His grief and actions, most of the time, reflects those of a father whose child was kidnapped.

The atmosphere is heavy and very depressing. Usually, the outdoor scenes are in gray or dark colors. They amplify the depression.
It contains many twists that make it more suspenseful. For example, the ending is different than most of the others of the same genre.

According to box office mojo dot com, below are the financial figures of this picture:
Production Budget: $46 million
  Domestic:  $60,604,828
+ Foreign:  $52,400,000
= Worldwide:  $113,004,828

So, it took in 67 million dollars more than its production cost. That's a huge amount.

In short, it's certainly worth watching.

"Prisoners" is a bleak, gripping mystery thriller that stays with you. It's a long and involving tale of two rural Pennsylvania families devastated by the theft of their young daughters on Thanksgiving Day and of a man so driven by the loss that he is willing to do almost anything to rescue them, consequences be damned. Comparisons to the films "Mystic River," "Gone Baby Gone," and "Silence of the Lambs" are inevitable, but don't let the fact that it's a genre picture deter you. The twists and turns of this confidently plotted drama will have you riveted to your seat, and the final scenes will give you more than one shock.

The film's running time of two-and-a-half hours is fully justified; there isn't a wasted moment on screen. I won't give away any details (if you want a plot synopsis, there's always Wikipedia), but be prepared to be put through an emotional wringer. The film, set in the late fall, is suffused with a wintery aura of dread and menace. The deliberate pace never lets us forget the seemingly endless wait that families of kidnapping victims must endure. Every clue that is dropped pitches us from hope into despair and back again. And a warning is in order: there are brutal scenes of torture that are deeply disturbing.

"Prisoners" is filled with searing performances by an A-list of Hollywood's finest actors, led by Hugh Jackman as a desperate father who becomes a frightening mirror image of the monsters he pursues and Jake Gyllenhaal as a dogged detective who confronts a labyrinthine web of horror and depravity. The other anguished parents are heartbreakingly played by Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, and Viola Davis, while Oscar-winner Melissa Leo appears as the mother of a disabled man, portrayed by Paul Dano, who is a prime suspect in the girls' disappearance. All of these actors, together with the film, director Denis Villeneuve, and screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski, will earn consideration for Academy Awards in 2014.

How far would you go?

Keller, along with his wife Grace, son Ralph, and daughter Anna are celebrating Thanksgiving dinner with their family friends the Birchs(Franklin, Nancy, Eliza, and Joy). But after arriving and settling in, both Joy and Anna are nowhere to be found.

It is hard to do a review on a movie this good, mainly because you want to describe what makes the movie so good and why you (the reviewer) feel that way. Prisoners is a good, maybe even great movie. It is a 2 hour + movie, but I guarantee you will not get bored watching this film. Every emotion, whether it be anxiety, loneliness, hope, and even sadness, you feel it with each character in the movie. That is mainly due to the acting, but also to the intensity of the story. Time does not feel like a factor watching the movie. Because in the end, everyone wants the same outcome.

As a whole, Prisoners scores high due to the Intense acting by both main/supporting actors. It succeeds even better with the emotional, drama-ridden storytelling that it brings to the table. Oscar buzz has been around Hugh Jackman's name as of late, and I gotta say rightfully so. The fearlessness and determination is unlike anything I've seen not just this year in in a movie, but in quite a while. I will definitely buy Prisoners on dvd. Prisoners gets a score of

4.5 Stars

Starring: Hugh Jackman, Terrence Howard, Jake Gyllenhaal, Viola Davis, Melissa Leo, Maria Bello, Paul Dano,

Warning: You will not see the end coming.

THIS IS A MUST SEE MOVIE FOR ANY MOVIE WATCHER THAT LOVES A GOOD MYSTERY THRILLER AND EXTEMELY WELL ACTED. "PRISONERS" IS SO WELL MADE FROM DIRECTING TO SCRIPT. ALL THE ACTORS IN THIS MOVIE DO AN EXCELLENT JOB OF TAKING US THROUGH THIS TRAGIC STORY OF CHILDREN COMING UP MISSING ON THANKSGIVING DAY. IT HAS BEEN A LONG TIME SINCE HOLLYWOOD HAS TREATED US WITH SUCH A GREAT MOVIE. I'M BUYING THIS MOVIE AS A PRE-ORDER BECAUSE IT'S DEFINITELY A KEEPER.

Can't wait to see more from this director. Two and a half hours glued to our seats! It just shows what you can do when you avoid the over-used shaky cam technique and allow the viewer to become absorbed in the story. Please, please, please let other directors see this movie and appreciate how a well composed, well edited, STEADY parade of images can draw an audience in by making them forget that they're watching a movie.

  When we see something of interest we stop and stare, we don't bob our heads around like prize fighters. This film is a beautiful case study in how people can be made to feel as if they are quietly watching a story unfold by NOT waving the camera around. It would have fallen flat if someone like Paul Greengrass had gotten his hands on it.

There is nothing new about detective dramas or crime dramas or detective/crime thrillers or any other variation thereof. Everything these days is the same old repetitious junk, cookie cutter TV production garbage. This is not the case with Prisoners.

Prisoners is a Silence of the Lambs caliber dark, terrifying and tension filled detective drama that breaks all the rules. This movie is not based on a true story, however It is a genuine look into the lives of everyone affected by a kidnapping. The story is appropriately and depressingly set in dreary rural Pennsylvania, where it always seems to be overcast and cold or rainy.

Almost all of the performances in this movie should be praised. Paul Dano has transformed himself into one of the best actors of his generation, his haunting performance is one that you will not soon forget. This is also one of Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman's best roles of their careers. The movie is long but it is very well paced, if you are paying close attention the anxiety may stay with you even after the movie ends. Just when you think something is going to happen a particular way, you are thrown for a loop. Nothing happens in this film by accident, it's all part of the plan.

PRISONERS, (2013). This crime drama/thriller, set in contemporary smalltown Pennsylvania, USA, examines the responses of  parents of kidnapped children to their desperate situation.  As written by Denis Villeneuve and directed by Aaron Guzikowski, this is one star-spangled suspenser.

To summarize the plot, let me quote from Warner Bros. Pictures, the releasing studio, as printed at IMDb:

How far would you go to protect your family? Keller Dover is facing every parent's worst nightmare. His six-year-old daughter, Anna, is missing, together with her young friend, Joy, and as minutes turn to hours, panic sets in. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street. Heading the investigation, Detective Loki arrests its driver, Alex Jones, but a lack of evidence forces his release. As the police pursue multiple leads and pressure mounts, knowing his child's life is at stake the frantic Dover decides he has no choice but to take matters into his own hands. But just how far will this desperate father go to protect his family?

Hugh Jackman, (WOLVERINE), as Keller Dover, turns in a towering performance that carries the picture.  Jake Gyllenhaal, (BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN), as Detective Loki, holds his own and then some, no easy thing.  Admired actor Terrence Howard (CRASH) plays Franklin Birch, father of Joy, the other missing girl.  Oscar-winning Viola Davis, (THE HELP), plays Nancy Birch, mother of Joy;  the Pennsylvania-born Maria Bello (A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE)  plays Grace Dover, mother of Anna.  Paul Dano plays Alex Jones, Oscar-winner Melissa Leo, (THE FIGHTER), plays Holly Jones, the aunt with whom he lives.  Dylan Minnette, who pops up everywhere playing teenage sons, plays Ralph, the Dovers' son.  Broadway favorite Len Cariou plays Father Patrick Dunn, an important supporting role.

The film is long, at 153 minutes, and I sometimes thought it could be cut by at least 30-45 minutes, particularly in some distasteful scenes apparently designed to illustrate techniques of `enhanced interrogation.'  It also seems some of us are meant to hate Keller Dover from the opening, in which he encourages his son to shoot a deer.  It is the first day of the state approved hunting season, Thanksgiving, no less.  Dover seems an illustration of the perceived-in-some-quarters gun-toting survivalist politics of the rural, poor mountainous Appalachian spine of the state, sandwiched between the richer and more liberal Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. I hated Dover throughout the picture, only to realize when I thought it over later that he was on to something all along.  Which is quite a feat of script-writing.  The presence of Melissa Leo in a supporting part is another illustration of the DePue dictum of casting: the presence of an actor more important/expensive than the part seems to require is a tipoff that the part's going to be more important than you think.  The squeamish might want to close their eyes sometimes, but thriller lovers will not want to miss this one.

Prisoners is an outstanding new mystery/thriller that manages to sustain its tension right to the last second. If you have seen the trailer, you know quite a bit about Prisoners. Hugh Jackman plays Keller Dover, a construction worker who lives in a quiet New England suburb with his wife (Maria Bello), teenage son, and six year old daughter. While spending Thanksgiving with the family of his life-long friend and neighbor, Franklin Birch (Terrance Howard), Keller and Franklin discover that both of their daughters are suddenly missing. After frantically searching the area, the only lead they have is a strange RV that was parked in the area. With the help of Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) and the police, they are able to track down the RV and apprehend a suspect (Paul Dano), but due to his mental incapacity and lack of evidence, he is released. This sends Prisoners in a harrowing new direction as Keller and Franklin wade through some ethically murky waters in the search for their daughters.

Prisoners does a phenomenal job of keeping its cards close to the vest. In its transition from drama to revenge thriller, director Denis Villenuve and writer Aaron Guzikowski do not force the film in any one direction continuously playing with the audience's sensibilities. Villenuve and Guzikowski are relative newcomers to the scene, although Villenuve did helm the 2010 Best Foreign Film Oscar nominee, Incendies. This is also a very smart movie in that it is not a run of the mill type of thriller. Several nuanced touches and motifs present themselves that allow the film to be absorbed to a deeper level, resulting in a film that stays with you long after you leave the theater. Take special note of the film's opening scene and revisit it after having seen the movie for a taste of what I'm talking about.
Image

Holy smokes! Look at all of those awards...sorry Paul Dano.

The film manages the gripping tone of films like Silence of the Lambs or Zodiac. The film also looks great. It was shot by Roger Deakins, known for his work with the Coen Brothers on most of their projects. With Prisoners, Deakins uses his static and deliberate camera movements to enhance every suspenseful opportunity. It's a tremendously well-crafted picture and a finely acted one as well. The film boasts Academy Award winners and nominees aplenty, and all of them are looking for more in this film. Gyllanhaal is especially good at elevating the traditional detective character to something more relatable, raw, and grounded. This is, however, Jackman's movie in every way. He takes the audience on a wild ride of emotion bringing just the right amount of crazy to keep us from judging his choices too harshly.

Prisoners is not just a good start to the fall movie season, it sets the bar. Few films offer such chilling emotion, engrossing action, and captivating performances, especially with running times of 158 minutes! This is truly an excellent film. A

Prisoners is rated R an has a running time of 2 hours and 38 minutes. Use the restroom before you start it because you won't want to miss a second of it.
A great dramatic who dunit, but when went to see it had a rowdy audence. will have to wait for the video release to fully enjoy it, or cable

***This review may contain spoilers***

The movie "Prisoners" simply starts with two families, the Dovers and the Birches, in a nondescript, blue-collar town, sharing a Thanksgiving dinner.  Then the two youngest members of both families, Anna Dover (Erin Gerasimovich) and Joy Birch (Kyla Drew Simmons) go to play outside supposedly under Anna's older brother Ralph's supervision.  They get close to a next-door neighbor's RV, but quickly leave when a pair of ominous eyes stare at them from inside.  Soon after, both nine-year old girls are missing and apparently kidnapped.  Methodical, persistent Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), with a perfect case-solving record, strives to find out who abducted the children and why.  There are a few suspects, but the most prominent one is Alex Jones (Paul Dano), a child-like young man who lives with caretaker aunt Holly (Melissa Leo) and who is arrested after violently trying to flee Loki and the police in the same RV. So now it's simply a matter of getting Alex to confess to the crime and reveal where the two girls are - isn't it?

Perhaps it's not so simple.  "Prisoners" spins an elaborate, deliberate, and intelligent mystery with its share of clues, red herrings, and frustrating dead ends.  But I believe the movie's primary focus IS reflected in its nuanced title and how the characters react to it.  Both families, including Grace Dover (Maria Bello), Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard), and Nancy Birch (Viola Davis) are understandably psychologically imprisoned by anxiety, suspense, tension, and horror at their loss - almost to the point of inertia.  However, Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) is not so passive.  He is imprisoned by more than just fear; he seethes with vengeance and wrath.  He is not satisfied with what he sees as cursory treatment of primary suspect Alex by Loki and the police and is enraged by Alex's release from custody due to insufficient evidence.  Insufficient evidence, hell! Keller, a home renovator, has his own ways of making Alex talk...

As the mystery progresses, "Prisoners" takes the time to explore Keller's struggle between justice and revenge and the viewer's attitude toward his actions.  As Keller retaliates with his own kidnapping and subsequent torture of Alex, I think many viewers will simultaneously sympathize with and be repelled by Keller's behavior.  If we lost a child, of course many of us would rage, and swear, and be spurred to some kind of action.  But would we do the things Keller does to Alex, things that begin to border on the sadistic?  As it winds toward the kidnapping resolution, the revelation of the culprit, Alex's fate, and, surprisingly, Keller's ironic fate,  "Prisoners" reminds us that no situation, even a kidnapping and possible torture, justifies letting ourselves being imprisoned by mindless and perhaps misguided vengeance.  In this regard, Detective Loki provides contrast.  Even though he gets violently frustrated by the case, Loki's professionalism and logic keep him on course and help him progress in his investigation.  Keller does not do the same for most of the movie until it's too late.  Like Loki, he learns the truth of the abduction, but his emotional prison may end up leading to a literal one as well.

The stuff that separates a good film from a great film can be so elusive. "Gone Baby Gone" is a kidnap based plot and it's one of my favorites. But seeing "Prisoners" put the entire genre in a whole new realm.

Here's the scoop. Set in rural Pennsylvania, two families are celebrating Thanksgiving when their two youngest daughters go missing. The police are called and the investigation begins. But the one father, Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) has his own ideas of what happened and pursues his own line of investigation. Both his work and that of the detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) take some surprising turns.

It's difficult to express how incredibly good this film is. Famed d.p. Roger Deakins lensed it and keeps the sheen off. This does not have the gloss of a Hollywood production. This is middle class America and you feel as though you are there with these people. The mud, rain, snow and budget furniture are things most of us have experienced. And the relationship between Gyllenhaal and his Captain is peculiar to say the least. Let's look at Gyllenhaal's Loki. First, he's named after the Norse God. He's great at what he does, But this is no slick, college educated guy. He looks as though he came up from the street. He's got a big tattoo on his neck. Others on his hands and knuckles (I'd love to know what those symbols represent). His clothes don't fit well and he seems to have no family or close friends. What an interesting character. And Hugh Jackman. I'm not a big fan of his because I just don't think he's that good, but he does a real stand-up job here. Far better than I've ever seen him. Same with Terrence Howard. This, for my dollar, is his best work. But Maria Bello, Paul Dano, Viola Davis, Melissa Leo all turn in great performances.

What really shines here is the script. You think you have things nailed down but it keeps twisting up to the end. And these aren't cheap plot turns. Though at first you might be scratching your head, all the loose ends come together in a very realistic fashion. The hand of God does come down in one crucial scene and part of the climax is a bit Hollywood but the rest is so outstanding it's easy to forgive it its weaknesses. And the ending. What a total creepfest.

If you liked "Gone Baby Gone" or "Mystic River" this is a must see.

Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) hunts deer the first day of hunting season. In Pennsylvania, that is Thanksgiving. His family walks over to the Grovers to celebrate the Holiday. While there, Franklin Grover (Terrence Howard) decides to entertain with his trumpet and the next thing you know their young daughters are missing. The son recalls a van nearby that the girls wanted to play on. The police (Jake Gyllenhaal) quickly get the van and the driver (Paul Dano), but it is clean and the driver "has the mind of a ten year old." To the dismay of Keller, the police let him go with the expected vigilante results by Keller.

As it turns out the tale is slightly more twisted than on the surface.

I will say the acting is good, but we have seen so many films of this genre they clearly ran out of catchy names and simply called this one "Prisoners" allowing the viewer to make everyone a prisoner either physically or of the mind. Yawn. I really liked the "Dirty Harry" version of this genre. Go ahead. Compare the dialog. Make my day. It took both Jackman and Gyllenhaal together to do what Eastwood did better by himself.

I am not saying this is a bad film, by no means. It is certainly worthy of a rental, especially if you like to see parents lament over their missing child. I just can't see shelling out a lot of green for a film that will remembered as a trivia question.

Parental Guide: F-bomb. No sex or nudity.

A crime has been committed and the culprit is Denis Villeneuve's Prisoners. The French Canadian director leads an all star cast in this crime thriller; which gained the attention of many moviegoers.. Already Prisoners is getting praise from critics everywhere; but does the crime thriller live up to the early reviews?

The story of Prisoners centers around a case of two missing girls. When Anna and Joy disappear on Thanksgiving, their families do everything in their power to look for them. It comes to the point where Keller Dover, played by Hugh Jackman, abducts and torture suspect Alex Jones. With Detective Loki, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, on the case, everyone involved will discover there is more going on then just a mere kidnapping.

Prisoners features a compelling plot that's not hard to follow. You will be guessing all the way through the 2 hour and 33 minute run time.  As a crime story goes, Prisoners is straight forward; but that does work for the movie. Nothing in the story feels it takes you out of the film; nor is there a twist there for the sake of being a twist. Everything in the plot fits, giving Prisoners a story fitting of the genre.

While Prisoners has a massive ensemble, the show-stealers are the leads: Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllehaal. While I can't say Hugh Jackman had a ground breaking performance, he still brought his charisma to Keller; creating one dynamic role for the actor. The same applies for Gyllenhaal's Detective Loki; though this is definitely one the actor's best roles in sometime. While the rest of the cast did not have monumental performances, they still fit and gave Prisoners a ensemble to be proud of.

What got my attention was the world of the movie. Denis Villenueve's direction in  the cinematography was perfect, giving Prisoners a realistic tone. That and the direction in some of scenes was awe-inspiring. The sequence of Detective Loki driving through traffic was tense and quite possible one of the best shot car scenes I've seen in a while.

Prisoners is everything a fan of crime films can hope for. The movie is tense and it keeps you guessing all the way through. Even if you are not shock by the twists in the film, you will be impressed by the movie's execution. Yes , Prisoners did commit a crime, and that crime was capturing this critic's approval.

You can also see the review here: [...]

"There's no way someone with the I.Q. of a 10 year old boy could abduct 2 girls in broad daylight and then somehow disappear." While at Thanksgiving at their friends house Keller Dover's (Jackman) daughter asks if her and her friend can run home and get a whistle. When they never return Detective Loki (Gyllenhaal) is called in and the search for the girls begins. When Keller thinks the police aren't doing enough he takes matters into his own hands and won't stop until his daughter is found. Based on the cast alone I was excited about seeing this. There are some movies you watch and laugh all the way through and come out feeling happy. There are some movies you watch all the time to relax you and have fun with. This is not one of those movies. While this is one of the best movies of the year and I honestly think Oscar nominations are not a long shot this movie leaves you feeling tense and uneasy the entire time. The fact that there is very little music helps create the tension it is going for. While this is a great movie and a must see this isn't one you can watch over and over due to the emotion and the way it makes you feel, especially if you are a parent. I highly recommend this but do not expect anything light and fun. Overall, one of the best movies of the year and one that sticks with you long after its over. I give it an A.

I admit, after seeing SO many lame movies in theaters over the summer that I had high hopes for(i.e. The Conjuring, Jobs, The Bling Ring), I was hoping that this movie would be as good as I hoped it would be, and it would also live up to the immense hype. Needless to say, it did!

This film is one where it really does help where you go in knowing nothing, and haven't watched any clips of it, except maybe the trailer. This is what I did. The movie may start out slow, but even the LITTLEST things that you may not think of as being significant, turn out to be. It is one long, gigantic mystery, and you never know what to expect! (Though near the end, I was able to accurately put together lots of clues/work them out.)

The film is very disturbing in some parts, too, but it is still excellent. The pacing is very good, the movie is very dark and creepy lighting wise, and the acting is good too. My favorite character was definitely Detective Loki--super handsome, smart, AND sweet in his own way. :)

Though the very ending wasn't my favorite, and there is one very questionable statement made by one of the little girls in one part that confused the heck out of me (and is never resolved/explained), this is still by far the best movie I've seen in theaters for awhile since Harry Potter ended, and one of my new faves! I will definitely be buying the blu-ray when it is available, and I urge anyone and everyone to see it!

*Also, there really wasn't a single boring part in this film, except maybe the whole Thanksgiving celebration. But like I said, the pacing is good and that isn't drawn out! But just PAY ATTENTION very closely. ;)

Director Villeneuve has you from the opening scenes of two families (1 black & 1 white) gathering for Thanksgiving in a Pennsylvania suburb, and the natural, easy joy they have in each other's company. But once you are aware a kidnapping has occurred, you are ALL IN until the harrowingly redemptive conclusion.

There is a strong thread of Judeo-Christian understanding informing this film, and it is pretty tough stuff. Not an ounce of easy reassurance in the script, performances, the ominous score or top-notch cinematography. You'll hear a telling section from the book of Job on a car radio. I thought the theological hints from earlier in the film should've been present in the closing scenes, too - it wasn't - but attentive and perceptive viewers will realize that, in addition to the masterful suspense, you have met some serious evil in this film. And this evil scars and deforms everyone, including the protagonists. Redemption in this life costs a lot, and the success of PRISONERS is that you understand this by the time the credits roll.

For me, best film of the year as of 9/26/13! But NOT for those looking for a night of pleasant entertainment.

If you are a parent or relative of a disabled person, YOU WILL NOT LIKE THIS MOVIE!  I have a disabled son, and I was disturbed by what they did to the disabled man in this movie, also, I thought it was a little boring,  I kept waiting for the action to pick up but it never did.  Loved the actors but HATED the movie.  WASTE OF MONEY!  I wouldn't by the DVD either!

"Prisoners" brings us some relatively new faces on the creative Hollywood scene and what they bring us is completely promising if not great. Veteran Coen Brothers cinematographer Roger Deakins lends his expertise to newcomer writer Aaron Guzikowski and Director Denis Villeneuve.  You can certainly see the influence of Deakins throughout the film and his beautiful take on reality in a chaotic situation.

This is one of those films that you don't want to know a thing about before you go. You don't even want to hear people brushstroke over it because even that is something you don't want to hear. For that matter, I won't even go close to going there. I will give you a brief introduction to what you should expect. Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) and his wife Grace (Maria Bello), walk down the street to their neighbors, Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard) and Nancy (Viola Davis). They each have a daughter and along the course of the evening, those two daughters disappear without a trace.

"Prisoners" is a gut-wrenching and fast running two and a-half hour movie. It is filmed in such a way that the events that unfold could involve you, your neighbor, somebody across town and on your local news.  Along with the way the movie is filmed and told, it is gifted with phenomenal actors that bring the reality of the situation to the surface.

It is an exhausting an emotionally filled movie from top to bottom and its subject matter will have your stomach in knots until the credits roll.  This, quite simply, is what movies are all about. Too often these days, movies make you feel nothing. Too many directors and writers are concerned with what you see and forget that first and foremost, what makes great cinema and long lasting cinema, is the feeling it leaves in your stomach and soul. At one point, Keller Dover's sadness effected me so much that I felt as if I was actually him or in the least, one of his family members or a great friend.

"Prisoners" is the kind of movie we should be flocking to the theaters to see until Hollywood gets the message that we want to feel something.  Sure, dazzle us with visuals, but until you relay empathy in your audience members, you have wasted millions of dollars and time.  "Prisoners" is tremendous filmmaking. It is one of the best and most complete films of the year and will almost certainly be a member of the Oscar night nominees.

Directed by Dennis Villeneuve, this crime thriller received a poor review in the local paper, but a strong recommendation from a friend prompted me to see it.  The movie played at the Toronto Film Festival before its release. It was the top box office draw the first weekend after its release on September 20.

At over 2.5 hours, "Prisoners" is long and begins slowly. The tension builds throughout, however, as the tangled plot develops. The film held my attention. In noting the commercial success of the movie, the "Los Angeles Times" aptly described it as a "head spinning hybrid combining elements that are rarely combined." These elements include noir and murder together with meditations on violence, vigilantism, religion, and parenting.

The two lead characters, Keller Dover and Detective Laki are played respectively by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhall.  Dover is a home repair contractor and a fundamentalist Christian. Laki is a tight-lipped, hardbitten, and successful tattooed detective. Gyllenhall's portrayal is a highlight of the movie.

Dover and his wife visit their friends and neighbors, the Birches, for Thanksgiving, and the two daughters of the couples are mysteriously abducted. The movie involves a search for the perpetrator with Laki the lead detective assigned to the case. Attention focuses on a young man, Alex Jones, (Paul Dano) who it turns out has the I.Q. of a boy of ten. When the police release Jones, Dover takes the law into his own hands and kidnaps and brutally beats him as the suspected abductor. The Birches back off from the cruelty but don't report Dover to the police. The convoluted plot develops through many twists as Laki works with determination to save the girls and find the kidnapper.

There are several "prisoners" to give the movie its title, including the two abducted girls and Alex. Possibly the chief "prisoner" is Dover, who is an internal prisoner of his fear, anger and thirst for vengeance.

The movie includes substantial and somewhat ersatz religious symbolism.
