Besides Dover's fundamentalism, (the hymn "What a Friend we have in Jesus" plays ironically throughout) the movie features a priest who is a sexual predator as well as characters who lose their religious faith when their young son dies of cancer. The primary focus, however, is on vengeance and viligantism.

The strengths of the movie include Gyllenhall's acting, the noir setting, including cold and snowy rainy nights, frightening special effects, dramatic tension, and the foreboding musical score.  The weaknesses include the complex, coincidence-driven plot, and an over-straining for symbols and meaning.

Given its hybrid character, and the mixed recommendations I received before seeing the film, viewers are likely to have differing responses to "Prisoners". I would not give it raves, but I found "Prisoners" well done and worth seeing.

Robin Friedman

Theatrical Review.  There may be spoilers.

Director Denis Villeneuve ("Incendies") asks the question, "What would you do if your child disappears?"  Hugh Jackman takes his Wolverine and Jean Valjean character's anger to a new level in this horrifying film.  He plays Keller Dover, a middle class Pennsylvanian who does work renovating houses.  His wife, Grace (Maria Bello) is a perfect companion.  Together they have 2 children.  Six year old Anna and teenage Ralph (Dylan Minnette).  They are having dinner at their neighbor and best friend's house.  Viola Davis and Terrence Howard are Nancy and Franklin Birch who have similar aged kids.  Young Eliza and teen daughter, Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons).

After dinner, the two younger kids want to go back to the Dover house to retrieve a doll or something.  Nobody's paying much attention until everyone realizes they never came back.  The search is on and after checking the neighborhood, the police are called.  Jake Gyllenhaal plays Detective Loki who heads up the search.  The police quickly track down a suspect who had been mysteriously parked in front of a vacant house in the neighborhood.  Alex Jones (Paul Dano) is the prime suspect, but he isn't talking.  Primarily because he has the mind of a 10 year old.  In addition, his RV that the girls had been playing on earlier, produced no evidence that the girls were ever there.

The two families, Keller in particular, are convinced that Jones knows where the girls are and are frustrated that he is released by the police.  As days past, Loki follows other clues while still focusing on Jones.  This doesn't satisfy Keller who eventually takes matters into his own hands and kidnaps Jones, holding him captive in an old apartment building he owns.  Villeneuve doesn't hold back as Keller beats Jones to a bloody pulp, later moving him to a small closet for some old fashion water torture.  While all this is going on, Loki finds another suspect unbeknownst to Keller.  So is Jones innocent after all?

Melissa Leo plays Holly Jones, Alex's adoptive aunt.  She's critical to the investigation, providing background to Alex's upbringing.  Her own background is a bit of a mystery, but both Loki and Keller continue to probe.  This movie is difficult to watch, not only because of the subject matter and torture scenes, but because it makes the viewer realize that there is an inner animal in all of us.  The writing is excellent, the cinematography is superb.  Strong performances by all but especially Jackman as Keller and Davis in her supporting role.  Dark and foreboding but a strong piece of filmmaking that will keep you talking well after the final credits roll.

This is a real review from seniors that went to see the movie yesterday. It has so much to it, we woke up this morning trying to answer questions with each other about what all happened. I can't wait for it to come out on DVD to watch it over and over. Go see this movie, you won't be sorry. I read the reviews and was really disappointed thinking that they aren't from ordinary people that go to the movies. I question reviewer Kristopher as to how he got all that information that scrolls at the end of the movie..really? Reviewer Goska, I felt bad for because of all the over analyzing.(try to just enjoy the movie). Reviewer Sawin gave in my opinion a good review. It just feels like so many of the reviews are fake anymore. I want honest opinions from people that just go to the movies for entertainment. I am sorry to have put all this in my review, but it is just hard to take anymore. The two and a half hours don't seem that long because of all the excitement going on. It is a hard movie to review because you don't want to give anything away. I came home and told all of my family to go see it. That is the highest recommendation I can give.

PRISONERS, Denis Villeneuveis's gritty thriller about the kidnapping of two young girls in suburban Pennsylvania, is definitely compelling.  But it's also totally over-the-top and laden with ridiculous coincidences that defy credibility.  The screenplay, by Aaron Guzikowski (CONTRABAND), gives us a number of interesting characters, including harried police detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), who is called in to investigate the disappearance of two girls on Thanksgiving Day.  The father of one of the girls, Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), goes from being cooperative with the police to full-on vigilante after the prime suspect -- Alex Jones (Paul Dano), a disturbed young man whose RV was seen parked in the Dovers' neighborhood - is released for lack of evidence.  Dover's wife Grace (Maria Bello) spends most of the movie in a semi-catatonic state, waiting for word of her missing child.  And the other girl's parents, Franklin and Nancy Birch (Terrance Howard and Viola Davis), are little more than background characters.  So what we get is two-and-a-half hours of unrelenting tension as Loki tries to unravel the case and Dover goes abu ghraib on hapless Jones.  How far is it permissible to go to save a child?  And are we all prisoners, trapped by circumstances beyond our control into behaving in ways that destroy us?

The biggest problem with the film, aside from its over-the-top sensationalism, is the number of coincidences that confound credibility.  [SPOILERS AHEAD -- proceed with caution!] Loki questions a priest who's on the sex offender list, and he finds a decomposed body in the basement.  Then there's a guy in a hoodie seen lurking around a candlelight vigil for the missing girls, and then later sneaking into their houses - turns out he's obsessed with mazes and has a thing for snakes and kids' clothes.  Loki also interviews the mother of a young boy who was kidnapped decades earlier under similar circumstances, a cute little boy seen riding his bike in videos.  Prime suspect Jones, who's described as having the IQ of a ten-year-old, lives with his aunt, whose husband disappeared five years before and hasn't been seen since.  All of these seemingly random events are ultimately connected like pieces in a jigsaw puzzle, fitting together to create an insidious picture of a world gone mad.  It's beyond soap opera, beyond anything that could pass for possible, and it undermines whatever impact the film ultimately delivers - or doesn't.

There are definitely hints in PRISONERS of other films with similar themes, like THE VANISHING (1993), A SIMPLE PLAN (1998), IN THE BEDROOM (2001), and MYSTIC RIVER (2003).  In all of them, there are kidnappings, misunderstandings, vigilante actions, and twisted endings.  Innocent people die in these films, and ostensibly good people do very bad things.  The point of MYSTIC RIVER seems to be that when we play vigilante, even with the best of motives, we become the monsters we seek to destroy.  PRISONERS never goes quite that far, as if Guzikowski and Villeneuveis aren't quite willing to take a stand on the horror they splash across the screen.  Is Jackman's Keller Dover a monster of his own making, or just a father doing everything he can to find his missing daughter?  In other words, is he channeling Liam Neeson from TAKEN (2008), or Sean Penn from MYSTIC RIVER?  Because it makes a difference, and those are two very different film.

I wish I had liked PRISONERS more, since it's one of the few films released this year that isn't about superheroes, comic books, or boob jokes.  For that reason alone, I hope it does well enough to encourage studios to continue producing adult films with intelligent scripts.  But I also wish the script were a bit more intelligent and a bit less sensational.  This isn't a bad film so much as a disappointing one.  With a cast like that it should have been amazing.  It isn't.  And that's a shame.  Watch it for the performances, for the bleak and unrelenting setting, and for the level of tension that never relents.  But be prepared for loose ends, over-the-top behavior (especially from Jackman's character), and enough coincidences to make the whole thing seem ultimately ridiculous.  It's worth talking about, though, and that's a good thing.  Not many movies are these days.

"Prisoners" 2013 Fine Performances, Evocative Direction, Screwball Script

I wanted to see "Prisoners" after I saw the trailer. Alas, the trailer contains all the best parts of the movie. Suburban parents celebrating Thanksgiving slowly come to realize that their two daughters are missing. The trailer featured quiet, dark scenes of increasing menace and despair, shot in realistic, autumnal, suburban settings. The trailer promised big, big stars: Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello as one set of parents and Viola Davis and Terence Howard as the other, Jake Gyllenhaal as the police detective, Paul Dano as the suspect and Melissa Leo as the suspect's adoptive parent. The trailer promised an intelligent thriller that would interrogate how far an ethical person could go in attempting to rescue his daughter from an abductor. The trailer also seemed to suggest an examination of how law enforcement responds, for better or worse, in child abduction cases.

The first twenty minutes of "Prisoners" delivered what I'd hoped for based on the trailer, but I was hyper-aware that I was watching scene after scene I'd already seen in the trailer.

Around the time that an unlikely body was found in an unlikely spot, and a fist met a face several times more than was necessary to make any point, but certainly enough times to satisfy a filmgoer's sick, sadistic bloodlust, the movie went off the rails for me, abandoned all its seriousness and intelligence, and became sensational gore and commercial pap. I was so let down I wanted to leave the theater, but I stayed because I'd roped two friends into seeing this with me.

"Prisoners" is a whodunit so there's a limit to what I can say without revealing any spoilers. I can say this. Jake Gyllenhaal powerfully performs a dedicated police detective. Hugh Jackman exercises his neck veins a lot, and his American accent is wobbly but okay. Terence Howard, Viola Davis, and Maria Bello are given criminally little to do. Viola Davis has one of the most interesting scenes in the movie. This scene is only a minute or two long and it is not developed at all. That is a shame because the scene is the moral crux of the film. And the film does nothing with it; the filmmakers went with implausible sensationalism and sadism rather than substance. Paul Dano, as the suspect, and Melissa Leo, as his adoptive mother, both give powerhouse performances in very challenging roles.

Denis Villeneuve's direction is flawless. He avoids explosive stunts and theatrics with his camera. His moves are slow and quiet, even while filming ugly violence. I'd like to see his work on a better script.

There are many attempts to make the movie deeper than it is. There are many scenes initially shot through dirty glass. "Through a glass darkly" is a line from the Bible. Ooo big symbolism. Wow. There are many crosses, including one hanging from the rearview mirror in Keller - Hugh Jackman's - truck. Wow. Heavy. I just may think something ... no, I'd rather watch snakes. Oh, yes. There are snakes. Some understand Satan as taking snake form in Genesis. Heavy. Profound! Yeah, not really. Just bizarrely implausible. There are strange character names. Hugh Jackman's first name is "Keller" which brings to mind the blind and deaf Helen Keller, or maybe the word "Killer." Jake Gyllenhaal is Detective Loki. Loki is the trickster God of Norse mythology. This is all pretty high school.

There are two scenes and one character treatment in this film that I found completely implausible. The two scenes are essential to the plot. I can't describe these two scenes but I can say that one is utterly implausible because of surveillance. The action of the film takes place within hours and days of a child abduction. Not only police, but also media and neighbors would be keeping an eagle eye on all suspects. Another scene is implausible because it demands that we forget everything we've been told about a key character. One character treatment is unbelievable to me because a very unlikely character is depicted as being as heroic, in his way, as John McCain. Not plausible. I also found the final resolution of the crime to be something that would only occur in a writer's imagination, and the ending to be pointlessly cute.

Again, the opening scenes of the dawning awareness that a child has been abducted are powerful, but the film totally lost me with its comic book sensationalism, sadism, and - I have to say it - stupidity.

"Prisoners" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: Keller Dover is facing every parent's worst nightmare. His six-year-old daughter Anna and her young friend Joy are missing, and as minutes turn to hours, panic sets in. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street. Heading the investigation, Detective Loki arrests its driver, Alex Jones, but a lack of evidence forces his release. As the police pursue multiple leads and pressure mounts, the frantic Dover decides he has no choice but to take matters into his own hands. But just how far will this desperate father go to protect his family?

The cast led by Hugh Jackman (in what possibly could be his best performance as Keller Dover), Jake Gyllenhaal (in another solidly-crafted performance as Detective Loki), Viola Davis (as Nancy Birch), Maria Bello (as Grace Dover), Terrence Howard (as Franklin Birch), Melissa Leo (as Holly Jones) & Paul Dano (as Alex Jones) is brilliant. The directing by Denis Villeneuve is brilliant. The story & screenplay by Aaron Guzikowski is brilliant.

The music by Johann Johannsson is brilliant. The cinematography by Roger Deakins is brilliant. The film editing by Joel Cox & Gary Roach is brilliant. The casting by Kerry Barden & Paul Schnee is brilliant. The production design by Patrice Vermette is brilliant. The art direction by Paul D. Kelly is brilliant. The set decoration by Frank Galline, set dressings by Molly Coffee, Deborah Croswell, Lucas Godfrey, Konrad Lewis, Blake Myers, Luke Myers & Ky Hoang Nguyen, set designs by Mayumi Konishi-Valentine & E. Aaron Linker is brilliant. The costume design by Renee April is brilliant. The prosthetic make-up effects by Mark Nieman is brilliant. The visual effects supervised by Vincent Cirelli, coordinated by Rebecca Park is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by Steven Ritzi is brilliant.

This is a brilliantly well-crafted, well-done film that is entertaining, intriguing & mesmerizing. Hugh Jackman gives another Oscar-worthy performance as Keller Dover & Jake Gyllenhaal gives another solidly-crafted performance yet again, as Detective Loki. Viola Davis, Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, Melissa Leo & Paul Dano round out this brilliantly-cast film with solidly-crafted performances of their own. Denis Villeneuve makes a brilliant American-film debut that is going to be awards worthy, especially Oscar-worthy. This is one of the best films of the year and one of the best films of the fall season, so far.

Hugh Jackman continues to be a huge draw and a well-respected A-list actor in Hollywood.  Even though he earned his popularity as the comic book character, Wolverine, in the X-Men films, it would appear his comic book drawing power isn't what it used to be.  Jackman's most recent film, The Wolverine, was a bit of a disappointment and prompted questions about whether or not his tenure of playing the character might be coming to an end in the not so distant future.  While this might disappoint comic book fans, it might not be the worst news since Jackman continues to thrive in dramatic roles.  Within the last year alone, Jackman has been nominated for an Academy Award and won a Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Musical or Comedy for his portrayal of Jean Valjean in Les Misérables.  Now, Hugh Jackman is back in a dramatic role once again for the mystery thriller, Prisoners.

Directed by Denis Villeneuve (Incendies), Prisoners stars Hugh Jackman as Keller Dover, a parent that is severely distraught after the sudden disappearance of his young daughter, Anna (Erin Gerasimovich) and her friend, Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons).  The local police quickly become involved as Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), a detective that has yet to leave a case unresolved, quickly targets Alex Jones (Paul Dano), as the potential kidnapper, despite a lack of evidence.  Regardless of the fact that Jones is a mentally challenged man and appears to be innocent, Keller decides to kidnap him and torture him anyway, believing he's the one holding the girls.  As the days pass and time continues to run out, Loki focuses on a variety of different possible suspects, all the while Dover and Joy's father, Franklin (Terrence Howard), continue their abusive attempts to make Jones reveal the whereabouts of the girls.  Viola Davis, Maria Bello, and David Dastmalchian also star in supporting roles.

First and foremost - as far as the story goes, Prisoners is an enjoyable thrill-ride from start to finish.  At no point does this story ever feel slow or lack entertainment value.  There is enough happening within this story that it will keep you guessing about which one of the characters is guilty, all the while wondering to what the extent the main characters will go to find out where their daughters are being held.  However, there is a bit too much story than there really needs to be - often spending too much time introducing new characters with no other purpose than to throw viewers off about whom the real guilty party turns out to be.  Naturally, the introduction of these characters causes the plot to balloon out to the point that the film might have some moviegoers checking their watch.  But, if the biggest complaint is about the movie being 15 minutes too long, that's usually a good sign for the overall quality of the flick.

Co-starring alongside Hugh Jackman is another Academy Award nominee, Jake Gyllenhaal.  Playing a relentless detective, Gyllenhaal most certainly shines in this role, although no more or less than in his most recent endeavors, such as End of Watch, Love & Other Drugs, and Zodiac.  Gyllenhaal has become a household name himself and although his scenes are not as emotionally involved as Jackman's scenes, he still gives a standout performance.  His slicked-back hair, nervous ticks, and tattoos depict him to be a hard-nosed, overzealous law enforcer that pushes the laws to the limit to retrieve vital information. In one particular scene, his character goes nose-to-nose with one of the potential kidnappers, which eventually ends with a needlessly bloody outcome - due to his character's lack of patience.  Clearly, Detective Loki (which feels like an Avengers plug) is the type of detective any parent would want on the street looking for their missing child.

While Jake Gyllenhaal is just as much of a main player as Hugh Jackman, he is easily outshined by Jackman's role of the emotionally distraught father.  It's unimaginable how it must feel to have you child kidnapped, but Jackman does a commanding job in the role as he goes through the periods of being fearful, angry, and eventually vengeful - nearly to the fullest extent.  He presses the relevant question, how far would you go as a father to find your kidnapped child?  The emotions flowing through Jackman's character makes for some extremely intense scenes, including a film scene-stealing in which Jackman's character faces off with Gyllenhaal's character outside a liquor store.  Even though Jackman's portrayal is absolutely flawless throughout the course of this mystery flick, this particular scene is a prime example of what drives people to go to movies in the first place.  This is dramatic acting at its absolutely finest.

The supporting cast of Prisoners follows the coattails of Jackman and Gyllenhaal closely.  The portrayals by Paul Dano as suspected kidnapper Alex Jones and Terrence Howard as parent Franklin Birch are both noteworthy, but are easily overshadowed and play second fiddle to A-list stars, not to mention the film's captivating storyline - written by Aaron Guzikowski.  Each interaction between the film's characters is better than the last as the film progresses, and as the scenes become tenser, it becomes abundantly clear that Guzikowski's feel for these characters is spot-on.  The writing and dialogue are obviously one of the main contributing factors in the overall success of this film.

Overall, Prisoners is gripping, mysterious, and a complete joy to witness, regardless of its traumatic nature.  Hugh Jackman gives the performance of a lifetime, and while it's difficult to say it's the best role of his career, it certainly includes one particular scene that will go down as one of his all-time most memorable moments.  Honestly, there isn't enough praise for the cast of this film, but it really is the plot that makes this such a unique and ambitious film.  And, the best part of this film is the end.  If you think you can see this film's outcome long before it happens, you'll be dead wrong.  You may guess who the "bad guy" turns out to be, but the last scene is completely unpredictable.  While the film might not have the most desirable ending for some, it absolutely has the proper ending.  Prisoners should quickly be added to the top of every must-see movie list and is easily one of the most recommended films of the year.  Enjoy.

GRADE:  A-

This is a perfect example of a film with inconsistencies, with implausible and sometimes even boneheaded actions on the part of the main characters, with irritating failures in reason and logic--but all of which we easily ignore, for the overall telling of the story is so superbly rendered.  The pacing, the atmosphere is so expertly developed, the acting so fine, that any lapses are swallowed up and overwhelmed by the excellence of the whole.

It's been a while since I've seen a film which establishes and maintains an atmosphere so strong and so in line with the subject matter.  Yes, the story is grim--and every scene of the film makes you feel it.  Yet it is not too much.  It does not wrench you into feeling its moments, but rather draws you in slowly and inexorably; it's as if we're apportioned a half-strength of the emotions felt by the characters.  This keeps us just comfortably out of harm's way, able to empathize, but enabling us to retain objectivity.  It's the perfect place I want to be, watching a story like this.
